INSTANCE: 201
PROBLEM: A basketball player is dribbling a basketball (continuously bouncing the ball off the ground).
H13:What forces are acting on the ball when it is moving upward and it is midway between the player's hand and the ground? Describe the motion of the ball at that moment.
A13:The ball has bounced off the floor
H12:Since the ball is not touching the floor, the floor cannot exert any contact force on the ball during this time.  The problem refers to the period of time when the ball is midway between the floor and the player's hand.  There are no contact forces on the ball during this period of time. What downward force does the Earth exert on the ball?
A12:gravity
H11:Can you articulate a law of physics which is relevant to this problem?
A11:newtons first law
H10:Let me try again. Which of Newton's laws is most relevant to this situation?
A10:second
H9:Bravo! What does Newton's second law say?
A9:An object in motion tends to stay in motion unless acted on by something
H8:Newton's second law says that acceleration equals ____  _____ divided by _____.
A8:mass
H7:Because it is a vector, acceleration provides what two types of information?
A7:speed
H6:Let me try again. Because acceleration is a vector, the information about the amount or quantity of acceleration is contained in the _____ of the acceleration.
A6:IDK
H5:Acceleration has information about both magnitude and what else?
A5:speed
H4:Now let's see if you can answer my original question in a complete sentence.  As a vector, acceleration provides what two types of information?
A4:Acceleration has information about both magnitude and direction
H3:What does Newton's second law tell you about the acceleration of the ball?
A3:it equals zero
H2:Let me try again. Since gravity is the only force acting on the ball, the direction of the net force on the ball is _____.
A2:downward
H1:Good job! Since the direction of the net force on the ball is downward, what does Newton's second law say about the direction of the ball's acceleration?
A1:its downward
Q: Since the ball's velocity is upward and its acceleration is downward, what is happening to <np id="201_1" min="velocity">the ball's velocity</np>?
A: <p id="201_0" refid="201_1">its</p> increasing
-------------------

INSTANCE: 204
PROBLEM: A basketball player is dribbling a basketball (continuously bouncing the ball off the ground).
H8:What forces are acting on the ball when it is moving upward and it is midway between the player's hand and the ground? Describe the motion of the ball at that moment.
A8:gravity
H7:Can you articulate a law of physics which is relevant to this problem?
A7:object in motion stays in motion
H6:Let me try again. Which of Newton's laws is most relevant to this situation?
A6:1st law
H5:Which of Newton's laws relates the acceleration of an object to the net force acting on the object and the object's mass?
A5:2nd law
H4:Bravo! What does Newton's second law say?
A4:F=ma
H3:Please use only words in your input. I am still a young tutor and I do not yet understand mathematical characters, such as +,-,*,/ or =.
A3:acceleration is parallel and directly porportional to force
H2:Newton's second law says that acceleration equals ____  _____ divided by _____.
A2:force mass acceleration
H1:Because it is a vector, acceleration provides what two types of information?
A1:direction and magnitude
Q: What does Newton's second law tell you about <np id="204_1" min="acceleration">the acceleration of the ball</np>?
A: <p id="204_0" refid="204_1">it</p> is equal to net force divided by mass

INSTANCE: 205
PROBLEM: A basketball player is dribbling a basketball (continuously bouncing the ball off the ground).
H1:What forces are acting on the ball when it is moving upward and it is midway between the player's hand and the ground? Describe the motion of the ball at that moment.
A1:the upward force of the ground and gravity
Q: Can you articulate a law of physics which is relevant to this problem?
A: Newton 's first law states that an object at rest will remain at rest and <np id="205_1" min="object">an object</np> in motion will remain in motion in a straight line at constant velocity unless there is an unbalanced force acting on <p id="205_0" refid="205_1">it</p> .
-------------------

PROBLEM: A basketball player is dribbling a basketball (continuously bouncing the ball off the ground).
H9:What forces are acting on the ball when it is moving upward and it is midway between the player's hand and the ground? Describe the motion of the ball at that moment.
A9:gravity is acting upon it
H8:Bravo! Does any other force act on the ball besides gravity?
A8:no
H7:Can you articulate a law of physics which is relevant to this problem?
A7:newtons law
H6:Let me try again. Which of Newton's laws is most relevant to this situation?
A6:2nd
H5:Right! What does Newton's second law say?
A5:The acceleration a of a body is parallel and directly proportional to the net force F acting on the body, is in the direction of the net force, and is inversely proportional to the mass m of the body
H4:Because it is a vector, acceleration provides what two types of information?
A4:speed and location
H3:Let me try again. Because acceleration is a vector, the information about the amount or quantity of acceleration is contained in the _____ of the acceleration.
A3:well i dont know that
H2:Acceleration has information about both magnitude and what else?
A2:distance
H1:Now let's see if you can answer my original question in a complete sentence.  As a vector, acceleration provides what two types of information?
A1:magnitude and direction
Q: What does Newton's second law tell you about <np id="209_1" min="acceleration">the acceleration of <np id="209_6" min="ball">the ball</np></np>?
A: <p id="209_0" refid="209_1">it</p> is proportional to the net force acting upon <p id="209_5" refid="209_6">it</p>

INSTANCE: 224
PROBLEM: A basketball player is dribbling a basketball (continuously bouncing the ball off the ground).
H11:What forces are acting on the ball when it is moving upward and it is midway between the player's hand and the ground? Describe the motion of the ball at that moment.
A11:the ball is moving up and the only force acting on it at that point is gravity
H10:Can you articulate a law of physics which is relevant to this problem?
A10:an object in motion stays in motion unless acted upon by an unbalanced force
H9:Let me try again. Which of Newton's laws is most relevant to this situation?
A9:the first
H8:Which of Newton's laws relates the acceleration of an object to the net force acting on the object and the object's mass?
A8:the third law
H7:What does Newton's second law say?
A7:i cannot recall
H6:Newton's second law says that acceleration equals ____  _____ divided by _____.
A6:it is divided by gravity
H5:Because it is a vector, acceleration provides what two types of information?
A5:the distance an object travels divided by the seconds squared
H4:Let me try again. Because acceleration is a vector, the information about the amount or quantity of acceleration is contained in the _____ of the acceleration.
A4:force
H3:Acceleration has information about both magnitude and what else?
A3:speed
H2:Now let's see if you can answer my original question in a complete sentence.  As a vector, acceleration provides what two types of information?
A2:acceleration provides both the magnitude and direction of an object
H1:What does Newton's second law tell you about the acceleration of the ball?
A1:that the speed the ball travels depends on the force applied to the ball divided by the mass of the ball
Q: Even though the ball is not touching anything during this time, there is a force acting on the ball. What does <np id="224_1" min="law">Newton's second law</np> tell you about the acceleration of the ball?
A: <p id="224_0" refid="224_1">it</p> tells <p id="224_5" refid="0">us</p> that the mass of the ball is smaller than the net force of gravity
-------------------
INSTANCE: 225
PROBLEM: A basketball player is dribbling a basketball (continuously bouncing the ball off the ground).
H14:What forces are acting on the ball when it is moving upward and it is midway between the player's hand and the ground? Describe the motion of the ball at that moment.
A14:the ball is moving up and the only force acting on it at that point is gravity
H13:Can you articulate a law of physics which is relevant to this problem?
A13:an object in motion stays in motion unless acted upon by an unbalanced force
H12:Let me try again. Which of Newton's laws is most relevant to this situation?
A12:the first
H11:Which of Newton's laws relates the acceleration of an object to the net force acting on the object and the object's mass?
A11:the third law
H10:What does Newton's second law say?
A10:i cannot recall
H9:Newton's second law says that acceleration equals ____  _____ divided by _____.
A9:it is divided by gravity
H8:Because it is a vector, acceleration provides what two types of information?
A8:the distance an object travels divided by the seconds squared
H7:Let me try again. Because acceleration is a vector, the information about the amount or quantity of acceleration is contained in the _____ of the acceleration.
A7:force
H6:Acceleration has information about both magnitude and what else?
A6:speed
H5:Now let's see if you can answer my original question in a complete sentence.  As a vector, acceleration provides what two types of information?
A5:acceleration provides both the magnitude and direction of an object
H4:What does Newton's second law tell you about the acceleration of the ball?
A4:that the speed the ball travels depends on the force applied to the ball divided by the mass of the ball
H3:Even though the ball is not touching anything during this time, there is a force acting on the ball. What does Newton's second law tell you about the acceleration of the ball?
A3:it tells us that the mass of the ball is smaller than the net force of gravity
H2:Yes. We already assessed that: GRAVITY is the ONLY force acting on the ball. Since gravity is the only force acting on the ball, the direction of the net force on the ball is _____.
A2:up
H1:Since the direction of the net force on the ball is downward, what does Newton's second law say about the direction of the ball's acceleration?
A1:the ball accelerates downward
Q: Since the ball's velocity is upward and its acceleration is downward, what is happening to <np id="225_1" min="velocity">the ball's velocity</np>?
A: <p id="225_0" refid="225_1">it</p> decreases
-------------------

Q: Your answer might be a little off the topic. Can you try to be more specific?
A: If <np id="242_1" min="object">an object</np> experiences no net force , then <p id="242_0" refid="242_1">its</p> velocity is constant : the object is either at rest ( if <p id="242_2" refid="242_1">its</p> velocity is zero ) , or <p id="242_4" refid="242_1">it</p> moves in a straight line with constant speed ( if <p id="242_6" refid="242_1">its</p> velocity is nonzero )

A: zero because <p id="254_0" refid="254_1">it</p> changes direction

INSTANCE: 264
PROBLEM: Two friends are standing over a bridge over a creek.  Each friend has a stone. Sarah throws her stone straight out from the bridge so that its initial velocity is horizontal. At the same time that Sarah's stone leaves her hand, Billy drops his stone so that it falls straight down.
H2:Which stone will hit the water first?
A2:Sarahs
H1:Remember that the vertical and horizontal motions are independent of each other. The decomposition principle says that the analyses of forces and motion along two _____ directions, such as horizontal and vertical, can be done _____.
A1:x and y
Q: How does the decomposition principle apply to this situation?
A: <np id="264_1" min="stone">Billy 's stone</np> is only going vertically so <p id="264_0" refid="264_1">it</p> will reach the water first
-------------------
INSTANCE: 265
PROBLEM: Two friends are standing over a bridge over a creek.  Each friend has a stone. Sarah throws her stone straight out from the bridge so that its initial velocity is horizontal. At the same time that Sarah's stone leaves her hand, Billy drops his stone so that it falls straight down.
H8:Which stone will hit the water first?
A8:Sarahs

A7:x and y
H6:How does the decomposition principle apply to this situation?
A6:Billy's stone is only going vertically so it will reach the water first
H5:Remember that the vertical and horizontal motions are independent of each other. How does the decomposition principle apply to this situation?
A5:Billy's stone has a vertical direction
H4:Let me try again. Because the vertical and horizontal components of motion are perpendicular, you can analyze them _____.  Because the question (about when the stones hit the water) relates strictly to the _____ component of motion, you don't need to consider the horizontal motion at all.
A4:independently vertical
H3:Can you state a relevant definition or principle?
A3:no
H2:Let me try again. What can you say about objects near earth upon which the only force acting is the force of gravity exerted by the earth?
A2:idk
H1:When only gravity is acting on an object it is said to be in _____. All objects near the surface of the earth freefall with the same _____ downward acceleration regardless of mass (neglecting the affects of air resistance).
A1:freefall constant
Q: Since <np id="265_1" min="stones">both stones</np> are released from the same height at the same time, and after release both are in freefall with the same constant acceleration, how do the times they take to hit the water compare?
A: <p id="265_0" refid="265_1">they</p> will hit the water at the same time

A1:independently vertical

After briefly answering the above question , please go on to explain your answer in as much detail as you can .
A:The forces acting upon the puck include gravity facing the downward direction , normal force pushing up and the applied force of the hockey player upon the puck moving in the horizontal direction . The <np id="1577_1" min="puck">puck</np> will remain in a constant motion and direction until the other hockey player applies a force upon <p id = "1577_0" refid = "1577_1">it</p> .

A:Since <p id = "1741_0" refid = "1741_1">it</p> is a constant speed , the tension in the rope is equal to the gravitational force acting on the child . constant velocity means the net force is 0, so tension and gravity must be balanced forces .

INSTANCE: 1947

INSTANCE: 1069

H2:Which ball will hit the ground first , ignoring air resistance ? Please begin by briefly answering the above question . Next , please go on to explain your answer in as much detail as you can .
A2:The balls will hit the ground at the same time . Since they both have the same acceleration due to gravity , the rate at which their speeds change is the same , and since they both start from rest , they hit the ground in the same time interval , with the same velocity .

PROBLEM:<np id="2897_1" min="sisters">Two sisters</np> are on a ledge over a deep swimming pool . Sue , the younger and smaller sister , takes a running start and goes straight off the ledge . Paulette , the older and larger sister , simply steps off the ledge at the same moment that Sue leaves the ledge .
H7:Which sister will hit the water first ?
A7:they will hit at the same time , because they both experience freefall with a constant downward acceleration of 9.8
H6:Which principle applies to this situation and why ?
A6:the decomposition principle
H5:Well done ! Why is the decomposition principle relevant here ?
A5:because there is motion in both the horizontal and vertical direciton
H4:The decomposition principle applies to this situation as one of the sisters , Sue , moves both __ _ _ _ _ _ and __ _ _ _ _ _ _ .
A4:horizontally and vertically
H3:How can the decomposition principle be applied to this situation ?
A3:because sue moves in the horizontal and vertical direction while her sister moves vertically
H2:Perfect ! How can the motion along the horizontal and vertical directions be treated ?
A2:the motion along the vertical direction can be treated the same because they are in freefall
H1:The __ _ _ _ _ _ and __ _ _ _ _ _ components of motion can be treated __ _ _ _ _ _ according to the decomposition principle .
A1:horizontal vertical independently
Q:How do the ideas of velocity , acceleration , and vectors apply to the girls 's motion in the vertical direction given that in that direction they are both in freefall ?
A:<p id = "2897_0" refid = "2897_1">they </p> both accelerate at 9.8 meters per second downward ,

INSTANCE: 1587
PROBLEM:Two hockey players pass a puck between them on an ice rink . Assume that the ice is very smooth so that there is no friction .
H9:What forces are acting on the puck while the puck is moving on the ice between the two players ? Describe the motion of the puck . Please begin by briefly answering the above question . After briefly answering the above question , please go on to explain your answer in as much detail as you can .
A9:gravity is acting on the puck . There is no friction because ice has a frictionless surface or at least very little so that it does n't play a role in this instance . Then , there is an applied force when the players hit the puck to pass to the other person .
H8:What are the forces acting on the puck while it is between the players ?
A8:gravity
H7:Let me try again . What force is the ice exerting on the puck that balances the downward force of gravity from Earth given that the puck is at rest vertically ?
A7:normal force ?
H6:Given all we learned so far , which of Newton 's laws can be applied to describe the motion of the puck while moving between players ?
A6:Newton 's First Law of Motion
H5:Possibly . Which of Newton 's laws describes the motion of objects on which a zero net force is being applied ?
A5:Newton 's Second Law of Motion
H4:Newton 's __ _ _ _ _ law can be applied to describe the motion of the puck given that the net force on the puck is zero .
A4:Second
H3:Can you articulate Newton 's first law ?
A3:An object at rest will remain at rest until an unbalanced outside force acts upon it , and an object in motion will remain in motion unless an unbalanced outside force acts upon it .
H2:What can you say about the trajectory and speed of the puck ?
A2:It 's constant because the net force acting on the puck while in motion is zero .
H1:Yes . We already assessed that : While the puck is between the players , there are no forces acting on the puck in the horizontal direction which means the net force acting on the puck in the horizontal direction is zero . What can you say about the trajectory of the puck given that the net force on the puck is zero ?
A1:It 's going in a straight line .
Q:What can you say about <np id="1587_1" min="speed">the speed of the puck</np> given that the net force on the puck is zero ?
A:<p id = "1587_0" refid = "1587_1">it</p> 's constant .

INSTANCE: 490
PROBLEM:A piano is hanging from a rope near the top floor of a building . The rope suddenly breaks and the piano starts falling . What can you say about the speed of the piano , which initially was at rest before the rope broke ? Assume no other forces are acting on the piano while in free fall .
H6:Please begin by briefly answering the above question . After briefly answering the above question , please go on to explain your answer in as much detail as you can .
A6:The piano moves at a constant velocity .
H5:That 's not right . The speed will be constant if a zero net force acted on the piano . However , in this situation the piano is in freefall which means gravity acts on the piano . Gravity equals the net force in freefall as no other forces are present . The Earth exerts a force of __ _ _ _ _ _ _ on all objects around it including all objects on or near its surface . The force of gravity points __ _ _ _ _ __ , towards the center of the Earth .
A5:The Earth exerts a force of gravity on all objects around it including all objects on or near its surface . The force of gravity points downwards , towards the center of the Earth .
H4:Which of Newton 's laws can be applied to the falling piano ?
A4:Newton 's first law states that an object at rest will remain at rest and an object in motion will remain in motion in astraight line at constant velocity unless there is an unbalanced force acting on it .
H3:Let me try again . Which of Newton 's laws explains the relation between net forces and acceleration ?
A3:Newton 's second law states that the net force acting on an object at any time will be equal to its mass times its acceleration at the time . We can write this as : Net Force equals mass times acceleration .
H2:What can you say about the acceleration of the piano based on Newton 's second law ?
A2:The acceleration of the piano is constant .
H1:Let me try again . What can you say about the acceleration of the piano based on Newton 's second law and the fact the force of gravity acts on the piano ?
A1:The acceleration of the piano is due to the force of gravity .
Q:The piano will have a __ _ _ _ _ acceleration due to the force of gravity acting on it . The acceleration is in the same direction as the net force which in this case points __ _ _ _ __ .
A:<np id="490_1" min="piano">The piano</np> will have a negative acceleration due to the force of gravity acting on <p id = "490_0" refid = "490_1">it</p> . The acceleration is in the same direction as the net force which in this case points downward .

INSTANCE: 1645
PROBLEM:To rescue a child who has fallen down a well , rescue workers fasten him to a rope , the other end of which is then reeled in by a machine . A5:The tension in the rope is equal to the downward force of gravity .
H4:Can you articulate the definition or principle that is most relevant to this problem ?
A4:newton 's seccond law .
H3:True , however Newton 's first law is even more relevant to this situation . What does Newton 's first law say ?
A3:An object in rest or in motion will stay at resto or in motion unless acted upon by a set of non-zero forces .
H2:What can you say about the net force on the kid ?
A2:the force of gravity equals the force of tension .
H1:Remember that tension and downward force of gravity are both vectors . In order for two vectors to be equal , the magnitude and the direction have to be the same . In this case , the tension is upward and gravity is downward . The MAGNITUDES of these vectors can be equal , but the vectors cannot be equal . What can you say about the net force on the kid ?
A1:the magnatude of the tension vector is larger .
Q:Remember than according to Newton ?s 2nd Law , an imbalance of forces ( or a non-zero net force ) causes an object to accelerate . While its true that in order for the child to start moving , there needs to be an imbalance of forces , in this case we are asking about a moment when the child is already moving and is moving at a constant velocity . What can you say about <np id="1645_1" min="net force">the net force</np> on the kid ?
A:<p id = "1645_0" refid = "1645_1">it</p> is unequal

PROBLEM:Tim is practicing his air hockey skills by taking shots at an unguarded goal . He hits a frictionless puck so it moves very fast directly towards the goal . A3:perpindicular
H2:How does the decomposition principle apply to this situation ?
A2:it says that the analyses of forces and motion along two perpendicular directions , such as horizontal and vertical , can be done independently . That is , Newton 's laws can be applied in each direction separately , without affecting the analysis of the other perpendicular direction .
H1:How does the decomposition principle apply to this situation ?
A1:ou almost got it . If a component of the net force on an object is zero , the object has a constant component of velocity in that direction . ( The constant component of velocity could be either zero or non-zero. )

How does the decomposition principle apply to this situation ?

A4:zero .

A10:They hit at the same time because they both begin with an initial vertical velocity of zero , and gravity affects them the same . Sue 's horizontal velocity has no effect on her vertical motion .
H9:Maybe . Which principle helps with solving problems by thinking of motion in two perpendicular directions ?
A9:decomposition principle
H8:Perfect ! Why is the decomposition principle relevant here ?
A8:Sue has a horizontal ( x ) velocity , but Paulette does not . The decomposition principle shows that Sue 's vertical ( Y ) motion can be considered seperately from her horizontal motion . The two sisters have the same vertical motion due to the equal acceleration of gravity .

A7:horizontal ( x ) vertical (y )

A5:seperately , as independent motions

A2:freefall magnitude of ( gravitational )

A1:they have no initial velocity . Gravity gives them a constant acceleration of 9.8 m/s/s . vectors show that their acceleration has the magnitude of gravity and the direction of downward . Vectors also allow Sue 's vertical frefall to be considered separately from her horizontal velocity .

INSTANCE: 672
PROBLEM:A parachutist is descending vertically at a constant speed of 2 meters per second .
H3:What is the net force on her ? What are the forces that add up to make the net force ?
A3:zero , gravity and air resistance
H2:Perhaps . Which of Newton 's laws describes motion of objects with constant velocity ?
A2:Newton 's first law
H1:Can you articulate Newton 's first law ?
A1:If the net force on an object is zero , then it is either at rest or moving in a straight line at constant speed .
Q:How can you apply Newton 's 1st law to the parachutist ?
A:Because <np id="672_1" min="parachutist">the parachutist</np> is moving at constant speed , the net force on <p id = "672_0" refid = "672_1" >him</p> must be zero .
-------------------
INSTANCE: 1551
PROBLEM:Two hockey players pass a puck between them on an ice rink . Assume that the ice is very smooth so that there is no friction .
H6:What forces are acting on the puck while the puck is moving on the ice between the two players ? Describe the motion of the puck . Please begin by briefly answering the above question . After briefly answering the above question , please go on to explain your answer in as much detail as you can .
A6:gravity and normal forces
H5:What can you say about net horizontal force on the puck while moving on ice between players ?
A5:equal to 0
H4:Possibly . While the puck is between the players , are there any forces acting on the puck in the horizontal direction ?
A4:the force placed by the hockey sticks
H3:Let 's get back to the previous question for a better look .
A3:no
H2:Given all we learned so far , which of Newton 's laws can be applied to describe the motion of the puck while moving between players ?
A2:1st
H1:Can you articulate Newton 's first law ?
A1:an object continues in the same speed and direction until acted upon by an unbalanced force
Q:What can you say about <np id="1551_1" min="trajectory and speed">the trajectory and speed of the puck</np> ?
A:<p id = "1551_0" refid = "1551_1">they </p> will remain constant
-------------------
INSTANCE: 2421
PROBLEM:An ice skater is moving in a circle by holding a rope that 's attached to the top of a post in the ice . Right at the point in the circle when she 's moving directly toward the hot chocolate stand ( due west ) , the rope breaks .
Q:In what direction does <np id="2421_1" min="skater">the skater</np> move after the rope breaks ? ( Assume the ice is very smooth so there is no friction . Ignore air resistance . )
A:in the direction <p id = "2421_0" refid = "2421_1" >she</p> is headed when the string breaks with a constant veloicty because newton 's first law tells <p id = "2421_2" refid = "0">us</p> that an object in a motion stays in motion until acted on by an outside force
-------------------
INSTANCE: 3558
PROBLEM:Tim is practicing his air hockey skills by taking shots at an unguarded goal . He hits a frictionless puck so it moves very fast directly towards the goal . His little brother Sam , standing on the side of the table , quickly nudges the puck as it passes the center of the table . The nudge is perpendicular to the original path of the puck .
H2:With this kind of nudge , could the puck 's new path ever be perpendicular to its original path ?
A2:it will not be perpendicular because there will still be a horizontal velocity towards the goal
H1:Maybe . Which principle can be applied when the motion of an object is complex , for instance , it can be thought of as motion in two perpendicular dimensions ?
A1:the decomposition principle
Q:How does the decomposition principle apply to this situation ?
A:after Sam nudges <p id = "3558_0" refid = "3558_1">it</p> , <np id="3558_1" min="puck">the puck</np> is moving in both the vertical and horizontal directions
-------------------
INSTANCE: 101
PROBLEM: A basketball player is dribbling a basketball (continuously bouncing the ball off the ground).
H11:What forces are acting on the ball when it is moving upward and it is midway between the player's hand and the ground? Describe the motion of the ball at that moment.
A11:The force exerted by the player and the force exerted by the ground
H10:Since the ball is not touching the floor, the floor cannot exert any contact force on the ball during this time.  The problem refers to the period of time when the ball is midway between the floor and the player's hand.  There are no contact forces on the ball during this period of time. What downward force does the Earth exert on the ball?
A10:Normal force
H9:Does any other force act on the ball besides gravity?
A9:Normal force
H8:_____ is the _____ force acting on the ball.
A8:gravity is the constant force acting on the ball
H7:Can you articulate a law of physics which is relevant to this problem?
A7:No.
H6:Let me try again. Which of Newton's laws is most relevant to this situation?
A6:newtons second law
H5:Excellent! What does Newton's second law say?
A5:force equals mass times acceleration.
H4:Because it is a vector, acceleration provides what two types of information?
A4:Magnitude and direction
H3:What does Newton's second law tell you about the acceleration of the ball?
A3:It is constant
H2:Let me try again. Since gravity is the only force acting on the ball, the direction of the net force on the ball is _____.
A2:zero
H1:Since the direction of the net force on the ball is downward, what does Newton's second law say about the direction of the ball's acceleration?
A1:the acceleration of the ball is downward
Q: Since the ball's velocity is upward and its acceleration is downward, what is happening to <np id="101_1" min="ball">the ball</np>'s velocity?
A: <p id="101_2" refid="101_1">It</p> is reaching terminal velocity or zero
-------------------

INSTANCE: 121
PROBLEM: A basketball player is dribbling a basketball (continuously bouncing the ball off the ground).
H9:What forces are acting on the ball when it is moving upward and it is midway between the player's hand and the ground? Describe the motion of the ball at that moment.
A9:Gravity, an upward force, it is also meeting some air resistance.
H8:Can you articulate a law of physics which is relevant to this problem?
A8:Newton's First Law
H7:Let me try again. Which of Newton's laws is most relevant to this situation?
A7:Newton's Third Law
H6:Which of Newton's laws relates the acceleration of an object to the net force acting on the object and the object's mass?
A6:Newton's Second Law
H5:Great! What does Newton's second law say?
A5:Force equal Acceleration times Mass
H4:Because it is a vector, acceleration provides what two types of information?
A4:It's direction and wether or not it is positive or negative
H3:Let me try again. Because acceleration is a vector, the information about the amount or quantity of acceleration is contained in the _____ of the acceleration.
A3:Magnitude
H2:Perfect! Acceleration has information about both magnitude and what else?
A2:direction
H1:Perfect! Now let's see if you can answer my original question in a complete sentence.  As a vector, acceleration provides what two types of information?
A1:Magnitude and Direction
Q: What does Newton's second law tell you about <np id="121_1" min="acceleration">the acceleration of the ball</np>?
A: That <p id="121_2" refid="121_1">it</p> is constant
-------------------
INSTANCE: 122
PROBLEM: A basketball player is dribbling a basketball (continuously bouncing the ball off the ground).
H13:What forces are acting on the ball when it is moving upward and it is midway between the player's hand and the ground? Describe the motion of the ball at that moment.

A11:Newton's Third Law

A10:Newton's Second Law
H9:Great! What does Newton's second law say?
A9:Force equal Acceleration times Mass
H8:Because it is a vector, acceleration provides what two types of information?
A8:It's direction and wether or not it is positive or negative
H7:Let me try again. Because acceleration is a vector, the information about the amount or quantity of acceleration is contained in the _____ of the acceleration.
A7:Magnitude
H6:Perfect! Acceleration has information about both magnitude and what else?
A6:direction
H5:Perfect! Now let's see if you can answer my original question in a complete sentence.  As a vector, acceleration provides what two types of information?
A5:Magnitude and Direction
H4:What does Newton's second law tell you about the acceleration of the ball?
A4:That it is constant
H3:Let me try again. Since gravity is the only force acting on the ball, the direction of the net force on the ball is _____.
A3:Downward
H2:Bravo! Since the direction of the net force on the ball is downward, what does Newton's second law say about the direction of the ball's acceleration?
A2:It is negative
H1:Since gravity is the only force acting on the ball, the net force on the ball is downward, so the ball's _____ must also be _____.
A1:accelaration downward
Q: Since the ball's velocity is upward and its acceleration is downward, what is happening to <np id="122_1" min="ball">the ball</np>'s velocity?
A: <p id="122_2" refid="*122_1">It</p> is slowing down

INSTANCE: 130
PROBLEM: A basketball player is dribbling a basketball (continuously bouncing the ball off the ground).
H1:What forces are acting on the ball when it is moving upward and it is midway between the player's hand and the ground? Describe the motion of the ball at that moment.
A1:The forces on the basketball include the force of gravity.
Q: Can you articulate a law of physics which is relevant to this problem?
A: Newton 's second law states that the net force acting on <np id="130_1" min="object">an object</np> at any time will be equal to <p id="130_2" refid="130_1">its</p> mass times <p id="130_3" refid="130_1">its</p> acceleration at the time . <p id="130_4" refid="0">We</p> can write this as : Net Force equals mass times acceleration .
-------------------
INSTANCE: 131
PROBLEM: A basketball player is dribbling a basketball (continuously bouncing the ball off the ground).
H6:What forces are acting on the ball when it is moving upward and it is midway between the player's hand and the ground? Describe the motion of the ball at that moment.
A6:The forces on the basketball include the force of gravity.
H5:Can you articulate a law of physics which is relevant to this problem?
A5:Newton's second law states that the net force acting on an object at any time will be equal to its mass times its acceleration at the time. We can write this as: Net Force equals mass times acceleration.
H4:Because it is a vector, acceleration provides what two types of information?
A4:Both the direction and magnitude.
H3:What does Newton's second law tell you about the acceleration of the ball?
A3:Newton's second law states that the net force acting on an object at any time will be equal to its mass times its acceleration at the time. We can write this as: Net Force equals mass times acceleration.
H2:Even though the ball is not touching anything during this time, there is a force acting on the ball. What does Newton's second law tell you about the acceleration of the ball?
A2:The ball is in free fall and experiences downward acceleration of gravity, which is 9.8 meters per second per second.
H1:Since the ball's velocity is upward and its acceleration is downward, what is happening to the ball's velocity?
A1:The ball's velocity is increasing.
Q: Let me try again. Since the ball's downward acceleration is in the opposite direction of it's upward velocity, the ball is _____ down.
A: Since <np id="131_1" min="ball">the ball</np> 's downward acceleration is in the opposite direction of <p id="131_2" refid="131_1">it</p> 's upward velocity , the ball is slowing down .
-------------------

A: <np id="132_1" min="objects">All objects in freefall</np> only have the gravitational force acting on <p id="132_2" refid="132_1">them</p> with a constant acceleration .

H4:Let me try again. Because acceleration is a vector, the information about the amount or quantity of acceleration is contained in the _____ of the acceleration.
A4:change
H3:Acceleration has information about both magnitude and what else?
A3:position or direction
H2:Good job! Now let's see if you can answer my original question in a complete sentence.  As a vector, acceleration provides what two types of information?
A2:Magnitude and position
H1:Acceleration is a vector.  Acceleration has both a _____ and a _____.
A1:magnitude and direction
Q: What does Newton's second law tell you about <np id="147_1" min="acceleration">the acceleration of the ball</np>?
A: <p id="147_2" refid="147_1">it</p> is equal to the net force divided by the mass of the object

INSTANCE: 148

A14:The ball is in freefall
H13:Let me try again. What downward force does the Earth exert on the ball?
A13:the force of gravity
H12:Can you articulate a law of physics which is relevant to this problem?
A12:When gravity is the only foce acting on an object that object is in free fall
H11:Yes. We already assessed that: GRAVITY is the ONLY force acting on the ball. Which of Newton's laws is most relevant to this situation?
A11:Newton's first law
H10:Which of Newton's laws relates the acceleration of an object to the net force acting on the object and the object's mass?
A10:Newtons's 2nd law
H9:Excellent! What does Newton's second law say?
A9:That the net force of an object is equal to its maas times its acceleration

A8:That the net force of an object is equal to its mass multiplied by its acceleration

H2:What does Newton's second law tell you about the acceleration of the ball?
A2:it is equal to the net force divided by the mass of the object
H1:Let me try again. Since gravity is the only force acting on the ball, the direction of the net force on the ball is _____.
A1:downward or negative

INSTANCE: 167
PROBLEM: A basketball player is dribbling a basketball (continuously bouncing the ball off the ground).
H6:What forces are acting on the ball when it is moving upward and it is midway between the player's hand and the ground? Describe the motion of the ball at that moment.
A6:gravity, normal force, applied force, and air resistance
H5:Bravo! Does any other force act on the ball besides gravity?
A5:normal force and applied force
H4:_____ is the _____ force acting on the ball.
A4:gravity, only
H3:Can you articulate a law of physics which is relevant to this problem?
A3:when one object acts on another, there will be an equal but opposite force from the second
H2:Even though the ball is not touching anything during this time, there is a force acting on the ball. Can you articulate a law of physics which is relevant to this problem?
A2:the net force applied to an object produces proportional acceleration
H1:Let me try again. Which of Newton's laws is most relevant to this situation?
A1:second
Q: Right! What does Newton's second law say?
A: The second law states that the net force on <np id="167_1" min="object">an object</np> is equal to the rate of change ( that is , the derivative ) of <p id="167_2" refid="167_1">its</p> linear momentum p in an inertial reference frame .
-------------------

A4:second

A2:it is downward

A1:crazy stuff

H7:Which of Newton's laws relates the acceleration of an object to the net force acting on the object and the object's mass?
A7:2nd
H6:Right! What does Newton's second law say?
A6:acceleration of a force is directly proportional to the force
H5:Newton's second law says that acceleration equals ____  _____ divided by _____.
A5:force. acceleration. mass
H4:Because it is a vector, acceleration provides what two types of information?
A4:It's directional
H3:Let me try again. Because acceleration is a vector, the information about the amount or quantity of acceleration is contained in the _____ of the acceleration.
A3:I don't know
H2:Acceleration has information about both magnitude and what else?
A2:rate
H1:Now let's see if you can answer my original question in a complete sentence.  As a vector, acceleration provides what two types of information?
A1:magnitude and direction
Q: What does Newton's second law tell you about <np id="193_1" min="acceleration">the acceleration of the ball</np>?
A: <p id="193_2" refid="193_1">it</p> is directly proportional to the net force

INSTANCE: 1326
PROBLEM:A mover pushes a desk with constant velocity v0 across a carpeted floor . Suddenly , the mover stops pushing . What can you say about the motion of the desk after the mover stops pushing ? Explain why .
H5:Please begin by briefly answering the above question . After briefly answering the above question , please go on to explain your answer in as much detail as you can .
A5:The object will imeditately begin to deccelerate as the force of frictoin acting in the opposite directoin will very quickly overcome the motion of the desk eventually bringing the dest to a stop .
H4:Which Newton 's law could be useful for solving this problem and why ?
A4:first because his first law discusses equal and opposite forces and it states that an object at rest will have a nt force of zero
H3:Bravo! Why can Newton 's first law be applied to this problem ?
A3:Because when friction slows the desk to a stop , the horizontal forces balance each other out creating a net force of zero . Also , the force of gravity and the normal force already cancel each other out creating a net force of zero in the y-direction .
H2:Let me ask the previous question again and try it one more time for a more accurate answer .
A2:In the end , the horizontal forces will balance each other out creating a net force of zero in the x-direction . The forces in the y-direction are already balanced because the upward normal force from the floor cancels the downward force of gravity creating a net force of zero in the y-direction as well .
H1:Newton 's first law could be useful as we can learn about the __ _ _ _ or total force acting on the desk when the desk was moving with constant velocity v0 .
A1:net
Q:Which other <np id="1326_1" min="Newton">Newton</np> 's law could help solve this problem and why ?
A:<p id = "1326_2" refid = "1326_1" >his</p> second law because this law states that the force on the object must equal <np id="1326_3" min="object">the object</np> 's mass times <p id = "1326_4" refid = "1326_3">its </p> acceleration . If there is no force there will be no acceleration and therefore no motion .
-------------------

INSTANCE: 2131
PROBLEM:A rocket pushes a meteor with constant force . Assume that the meteor is initially at rest and is far enough away from the sun and the planets to neglect gravity . How will the meteor move ?
Q:Please begin by briefly answering the above question . After briefly answering the above question , please go on to explain your answer in as much detail as you can .
A:The meteor will move at the same velocity as the rocket . Based on Newton 's First law , anything at rest will remain at rest until an unbalanced force occurs . In this case , the rocket provides the unbalanced force onto <np id="2131_1" min="meteor">the meteor</np> , causing <p id = "2131_2" refid = "2131_1">it</p> to move .

INSTANCE: 2132
PROBLEM:A rocket pushes a meteor with constant force . Assume that the meteor is initially at rest and is far enough away from the sun and the planets to neglect gravity . How will the meteor move ?
H1:Please begin by briefly answering the above question . After briefly answering the above question , please go on to explain your answer in as much detail as you can .
A1:The meteor will move at the same velocity as the rocket . Based on Newton 's First law , anything at rest will remain at rest until an unbalanced force occurs . In this case , the rocket provides the unbalanced force onto the meteor , causing it to move .
Q:Can you articulate Newton 's second law ?
A:Newon 's second law is that the net force of <np id="2132_1" min="object">an object</np> at any given moment will be <p id = "2132_2" refid = "2132_1">it</p> 's mass multiplied by <p id = "2132_3" refid = "2132_1">its </p> acceleration .

PROBLEM:A piano is hanging from a rope near the top floor of a building . The rope suddenly breaks and the piano starts falling . What can you say about the speed of the piano , which initially was at rest before the rope broke ? Assume no other forces are acting on the piano while in free fall .
H10:Please begin by briefly answering the above question . After briefly answering the above question , please go on to explain your answer in as much detail as you can .
A10:it is accelerating
H9:What force does the Earth exert on all objects on it ?
A9:gravity
H8:Which of Newton 's laws can be applied to the falling piano ?
A8:the 2nd
H7:Perfect ! Why is Newton 's second relevant to the falling piano ?
A7:it is deccelerating
H6:Newton 's second law applies because the piano is acted upon with a non-zero __ _ _ _ _ force . The net force is the same as the force of gravity in this case as no other forces act on the piano while on freefall .
A6:slowing down
H5:Can you articulate Newton 's second law ?
A5:gravity
H4:Let me try again . What does Newton 's second law say about net force , mass , and acceleration ?
A4:it is accelerating
H3:Newton 's second law says that the net force equals __ _ _ _ times __ _ __ .
A3:__ _ times __ _ _
H2:What can you say about the acceleration of the piano based on Newton 's second law ?
A2:mass times acceleration
H1:Yes . We already assessed that : Newton 's second law says that NET FORCE equals MASS times ACCELERATION. It also says that the NET FORCE and the ACCELERATION are always in the SAME DIRECTION. What can you say about the acceleration of the piano based on Newton 's second law and the fact the force of gravity acts on the piano ?
A1:force equals mass times acceleration
Q:The piano will have a __ _ _ _ _ acceleration due to the force of gravity acting on it . The acceleration is in the same direction as the net force which in this case points __ _ _ _ __ .
A:<p id = "558_1" refid = "0">I</p> 've already answered <p id = "558_2" refid = "0">you</p>

A4:the horizontal force is exerted by the players

A3:it is decreasing
H2:Let me try again . While the puck is between the players , are there any forces acting on the puck in the horizontal direction ?
A2:no
H1:Given all we learned so far , which of Newton 's laws can be applied to describe the motion of the puck while moving between players ?
A1:the motion of the puck is in a straight line and at a decreasing velocity

A:<p id = "1510_2" refid = "1510_1">it</p> will move in a straight line at a constant velocity

A1:Law of Decomposition because the vectors are analyzed separately .

A:Only the y-velocity matters here since <p id = "3158_2" refid = "3158_1">they</p> are going up and down , and both sisters ' initial velocity was zero .

PROBLEM:Two friends are standing over a bridge over a creek . Each friend has a stone . Sarah throws her stone straight out from the bridge so that its initial velocity is horizontal . At the same time that Sarah 's stone leaves her hand , Billy drops his stone so that it falls straight down .

A8:Okay , I have thoroughly considered the problem . Would you like me to actually answer the question ? In the case that you do , both stones will hit the water at the same time .

A7:Both stones will hit the water at the same time .
H6:What principle can be applied when analyzing motion in perpendicular directions such as horizontal and vertical directions ?
A6:The decomposition principle
H5:How does the decomposition principle apply to this situation ?
A5:Both of the stones are dropped with an initial vertical velocity of zero , while experiencing the same acceleration due to gravity . The decomposition principle applies as the horizontal component of velocity of Sarah 's stone does not affect the vertical component of velocity .
H4:Maybe . Which direction of motion is relevant to the focus of this problem ?
A4:Vertical

A3:I do n't know exactly what you 're asking for .

A2:They will experience the same downwards acceleration due to gravity

A1:freefall constant

A:<np id="3222_1" min="stones">Both stones</np> are in freefall as the only force acting upon <p id = "3222_2" refid = "3222_1">them</p> ( neglecting air resistance ) is the downwards force of gravity

INSTANCE: 1656
PROBLEM:To rescue a child who has fallen down a well , rescue workers fasten him to a rope , the other end of which is then reeled in by a machine . The rope pulls the child straight upward at steady speed . How does the amount of tension in the rope compare to the downward force of gravity acting on the child ?
H8:Please begin by briefly answering the above question . After briefly answering the above question , please go on to explain your answer in as much detail as you can .
A8:The tension in the rope is greater than the force of gravity .
H7:Remember than according to Newton ?s 2nd Law , an imbalance of forces ( or a non-zero net force ) causes an object to accelerate . While its true that in order for the child to start moving , there needs to be an imbalance of forces , in this case we are asking about a moment when the child is already moving and is moving at a constant velocity . What does Newton 's first law say about an object 's motion and net force ?
A7:an object in motion will remain in motion

A6:non zero

A4:tension and force of gravity

PROBLEM:Two sisters are on a ledge over a deep swimming pool . Sue , the younger and smaller sister , takes a running start and goes straight off the ledge . Paulette , the older and larger sister , simply steps off the ledge at the same moment that Sue leaves the ledge .
H15:Which sister will hit the water first ?
A15:they both hit the water at the same time
H14:Which principle applies to this situation and why ?
A14:free fall because only gravity is acting on them
H13:Let me try again . Which principle helps with solving problems by thinking of motion in two perpendicular directions ?
A13:decomposition
H12:Right ! Why is the decomposition principle relevant here ?
A12:they are in freefall
H11:The decomposition principle applies to this situation as one of the sisters , Sue , moves both __ _ _ _ _ _ and __ _ _ _ _ _ _ .
A11:horizontaly and verticaly
H10:How can the decomposition principle be applied to this situation ?
A10:sue moves both horizontally and vertically
H9:Perfect ! How can the motion along the horizontal and vertical directions be treated ?
A9:as decomposition
H8:The __ _ _ _ _ _ and __ _ _ _ _ _ components of motion can be treated __ _ _ _ _ _ according to the decomposition principle .
A8:horizontal vertical similarly
H7:Can you state a relevant definition or principle ?
A7:no
H6:Let me try again . What can you say about objects near earth upon which the only force acting is the force of gravity exerted by the earth ?
A6:they are in freefall
H5:How do the ideas of velocity , acceleration , and vectors apply to the girls 's motion in the vertical direction given that in that direction they are both in freefall ?
A5:they dont
H4:Let me try again . The girls have the same __ _ _ _ _ in the vertical direction .
A4:acceleration
H3:While it is true they have the same acceleration , the answer we were looking for is position . When they start falling they have an initial vertical velocity of __ _ _ __ .
A3:0
H2:Perfect ! The only force acting on them is gravity , so they are in __ _ __ , and therefore have __ _ _ _ vertical accelerations .
A2:freefall same
H1:Right ! Because initial vertical position , initial vertical velocity and vertical acceleration are the same in the vertical direction , the vertical component of their motion is __ _ __ .
A1:vertical
Q:What do the above information about position , velocity , and acceleration in the vertical direction tell us about the time it takes for <np id="3086_1" min="girls">the girls</np> to hit the water ?
A:<p id = "3086_2" refid = "-1">it</p> takes the same time because <p id = "3086_3" refid = "3086_1">they</p> are both in freefall

INSTANCE: 635
PROBLEM:A parachutist is descending vertically at a constant speed of 2 meters per second .
H9:What is the net force on her ? What are the forces that add up to make the net force ?
A9:0 force . Acceleration due to gravity and resistance due to the parachute
H8:Maybe . Which of Newton 's laws describes motion of objects with constant velocity ?
A8:His first law
H7:Can you articulate Newton 's first law ?
A7:Objects in motion will stay in motion until acted upon by an outside force . Objects at rest will stay at rest until acted upon by an outside force .
H6:How can you apply Newton 's 1st law to the parachutist ?
A6:The resistance from the parachute is equal in magnitude but opposite to direction to the acceleration due to graivty therefore it remains in constant velocity .
H5:How can you apply Newton 's 1st law to the parachutist ?
A5:The resistance from the parachute is equal to that of gravitiy 's acceleration therefore netting a 0 force leaving the parachutist at a constant velocity .
H4:Yes . We already assessed that : Newton 's first law says that if the net force on an object is ZERO the object is either AT REST (zero velocity ) OR moves with a CONSTANT velocity in a STRAIGHT LINE. Zero net force could be the result of no force at all acting on an object or the result of BALANCED forces ( balanced forces cancel each other out by acting in opposite directions ) . According to Newton 's first law , what is the net force on an object moving at constant speed ?
A4:0
H3:Since the parachutist is moving at a constant speed , the net force on her must be __ _ _ __ .
A3:0
H2:So , what can you say briefly about the net force on the parachutist ?
A2:It is 0
H1:Can you articulate Newton 's second law ?
A1:Force equals mass times acceleration
Q:What does Newton 's second law tell you about <np id="635_1" min="direction">the direction of the net force on the parachutist</np> ?
A:<p id = "635_2" refid = "635_1">It</p> is upward
-------------------

A7:because the object remains in motion

A6:gravity

INSTANCE: 3515
PROBLEM:Tim is practicing his air hockey skills by taking shots at an unguarded goal . He hits a frictionless puck so it moves very fast directly towards the goal . His little brother Sam , standing on the side of the table , quickly nudges the puck as it passes the center of the table . The nudge is perpendicular to the original path of the puck .
H7:With this kind of nudge , could the puck 's new path ever be perpendicular to its original path ?
A7:No
H6:Let me try again . Which principle can be applied when the motion of an object is complex , for instance , it can be thought of as motion in two perpendicular dimensions ?
A6:Decomposition principle
H5:How does the decomposition principle apply to this situation ?
A5:There is an up and down direction
H4:Let me try again . We will first analyze the puck 's motion in the direction of the goal , and then __ _ _ _ analyze the puck 's motion in the perpendicular direction . Then , we will __ _ _ _ the information about the puck 's motions in the direction of the goal and in the perpendicular direction to determine the puck 's path .
A4:we will , analyze
H3:Can you articulate the definition or principle that is most relevant to this problem ?
A3:Decomposition principle
H2:Let me try again . Which of Newton 's laws is most relevant to this situation ?
A2:Newton 's First Law
H1:Perfect ! What does Newton 's first law say ?
A1:An object in motion has a constant speed and direction unless acted upon by an unbalanced force

A1:an object in motion will remain in motion and an object at rest will remain at rest at a constant speed and accerleration unless acted upon by an unbalanced force
Q:What can you say about <np id="1605_1" min="trajectory and speed">the trajectory and speed of the puck </np>?
A:<p id = "1605_2" refid = "1605_1">it</p> is constant and in the same direction

INSTANCE: 3155
PROBLEM:Two sisters are on a ledge over a deep swimming pool . Sue , the younger and smaller sister , takes a running start and goes straight off the ledge . Paulette , the older and larger sister , simply steps off the ledge at the same moment that Sue leaves the ledge .
H7:Which sister will hit the water first ?
A7:They hit at the same time because they both begin with an initial vertical velocity of zero , and gravity affects them the same . Sue 's horizontal velocity has no effect on her vertical motion .
H6:Maybe . Which principle helps with solving problems by thinking of motion in two perpendicular directions ?
A6:decomposition principle
H5:Perfect ! Why is the decomposition principle relevant here ?
A5:Sue has a horizontal ( x ) velocity , but Paulette does not . The decomposition principle shows that Sue 's vertical ( Y ) motion can be considered seperately from her horizontal motion . The two sisters have the same vertical motion due to the equal acceleration of gravity .
H4:The decomposition principle applies to this situation as one of the sisters , Sue , moves both __ _ _ _ _ _ and __ _ _ _ _ _ _ .
A4:horizontal ( x ) vertical (y )
H3:How can the decomposition principle be applied to this situation ?
A3:It can allow us to calculate Sue 's vertical (y ) motion without her horizontal ( x ) motion interfearing
H2:Bravo! How can the motion along the horizontal and vertical directions be treated ?
A2:seperately , as independent motions
H1:Can you state a relevant definition or principle ?
A1:decomposition principle
Q:Let me try again . What can you say about <np id="3155_3" min="objects">objects near earth</np> upon which the only force acting is <np id="3155_1" min="force">the force of gravity exerted by the earth </np> ?
A:<p id = "3155_2" refid = "3155_1">it</p> effects <p id = "3155_4" refid = "3155_3">them</p> equally . Newton 's third law

INSTANCE: 1269
PROBLEM:A mover pushes a desk with constant velocity v0 across a carpeted floor . Suddenly , the mover stops pushing . What can you say about the motion of the desk after the mover stops pushing ? Explain why .
H7:Please begin by briefly answering the above question . After briefly answering the above question , please go on to explain your answer in as much detail as you can .
A7:The desk will slow down and come to a stop . The force of friction will cause the desk to slow down and then stop .
H6:If the mover stops pushing the desk , the desk will not move with constant velocity but rather with decreasing velocity as the only force acting on the desk will be friction . Friction acts in the opposite direction of the desk 's movement thus slowing the desk down . Newton 's __ _ _ _ _ _ law could be useful as we can learn about the net or total force acting on the desk when the desk was moving with constant velocity v0 .
A6:second
H5:Which other Newton 's law could help solve this problem and why ?
A5:third . The negative force of friction is equal to the force on the desk when it is released .
H4:Which other Newton 's law could help solve this problem and why ?
A4:newton 's third law because the force of friction equals the negative amount of force that was initially applied on the desk

INSTANCE: 3511
PROBLEM:Tim is practicing his air hockey skills by taking shots at an unguarded goal . He hits a frictionless puck so it moves very fast directly towards the goal . H7:With this kind of nudge , could the puck 's new path ever be perpendicular to its original path ?
A7:No
H6:Let me try again . Which principle can be applied when the motion of an object is complex , for instance , it can be thought of as motion in two perpendicular dimensions ?
A6:decomposition
H5:How does the decomposition principle apply to this situation ?
A5:the is complex motion
H4:In order for the puck 's new path to be completely perpendicular to its original path toward the goal , the puck 's component of velocity in the direction of the goal would have to change to zero . Newton 's laws tells us that a component of net force in the opposite direction from the goal would be necessary to reduce the puck 's component of velocity in the direction of the goal . Since we assume the ice to be frictionless and ignore air resistance , and since Sam 's nudge is perpendicular to the puck 's original path , there are no forces that could change the puck 's component of velocity in the direction of the goal . How does the decomposition principle apply to this situation ?
A4:It allows us to seperate the original velocity from the nudge
H3:Let me try again . We will first analyze the puck 's motion in the direction of the goal , and then __ _ _ _ analyze the puck 's motion in the perpendicular direction . Then , we will __ _ _ _ the information about the puck 's motions in the direction of the goal and in the perpendicular direction to determine the puck 's path .
A3:separately combine
H2:Can you articulate the definition or principle that is most relevant to this problem ?
A2:the decomposition principle
H1:Let me try again . Which of Newton 's laws is most relevant to this situation ?
A1:second
Q:True , however Newton 's first law is even more relevant to this situation . What does Newton 's first law say ?
A:that when the net force on <np id="3511_1" min="object">a object</np> is zero , <p id = "3511_2" refid = "3511_1">it</p> wil either remain at rest or move in a straight line at constant velocity

INSTANCE: 2316
PROBLEM:A hockey puck rests in the middle of an ice rink . What forces are acting on the puck ?
H1:Please begin by briefly answering the above question . After briefly answering the above question , please go on to explain your answer in as much detail as you can .
A1:The force of gravity and the normal force are acting on the puck . Since , we assume , the ice rink is on Earth , there is a force of gravity acting on it . Because the puck is at rest , that means there must be a force countering the force of gravity , which is the normal force of the rink acting on the puck . Since the puck is at rest , this means there are no horizontal forces acting on it . So , only the force of gravity and the normal force act on the puck .
Q:Well , if only gravity were acting on the puck vertically , the puck would not be at rest in the vertical direction but rather move with the gravitational acceleration downwards . Which one of Newton 's laws talks about objects at rest ?
A:Newton 's first law talks about objects at rest . <p id = "2316_1" refid = "0">I</p> had said that the normal force acted upon the puck as a counter to gravity before , but perhaps that did not register because <p id = "2316_2" refid = "0">I</p> did not mention Newton 's first law .

INSTANCE: 342
PROBLEM:Two friends are standing over a bridge over a creek . Each friend has a stone . Sarah throws her stone straight out from the bridge so that its initial velocity is horizontal . At the same time that Sarah 's stone leaves her hand , Billy drops his stone so that it falls straight down .

A3:perpendicular algebraically

A2:Sarah 's stone has both horizontal and veritcal directions .
H1:Remember that the vertical and horizontal motions are independent of each other . How does the decomposition principle apply to this situation ?
A1:Sarah 's stone has both horizontal and vertical motion .

A:Because the vertical motion of <np id="342_1" min="stone">Sarah 's stone</np> is independent of <p id = "342_2" refid = "342_1">its </p> horizontal motion , the two stones released at the same time will strike the water at the same time .

INSTANCE: 1824
PROBLEM:A piano is lowered straight down from a top floor apartment by a rope and is moving at constant velocity . How does the tension in the rope compare to the downward force of gravity ?
H7:Please begin by briefly answering the above question . After briefly answering the above question , please go on to explain your answer in as much detail as you can .
A7:TENSION EEQUALS gravity
H6:Let me try again . What does Newton 's first law say about an object 's motion and net force ?
A6:if net force is 0 then motion is constant
H5:How does Newton 's first law apply to the piano being lowered down with constant speed ?
A5:the net force is 0
H4:Remember that tension and downward force of gravity are both vectors . In order for two vectors to be equal , the magnitude and the direction have to be the same . In this case , the tension is upward and gravity is downward . The MAGNITUDES of these vectors can be equal , but the vectors cannot be equal . How does Newton 's first law apply to the piano being lowered down with constant speed ?
A4:the net force is 0
H3:Let me try again . Because the piano moves straight downwards with a constant velocity , what can you say about the net force acting on it ?
A3:it is 0
H2:What are the forces acting on the piano and which make up the net force ( which is zero , as we just learned ) ?
A2:tension and gravity
H1:So , how would you compare the amounts ( or magnitudes ) of the tensions force that pulls the piano upwards and the gravity force that pulls the piano downward ?
A1:they are equal
Q:Maybe . Because the net force on the piano is zero , what can you say about <np id="1824_1" min="forces">the individual forces acting on the piano</np> ?
A:<p id = "1824_2" refid = "1824_1">they </p> balance out
-------------------

A1:a object in motion stays in motion unlesss a net force is acting upon it

INSTANCE: 3292

H1:Will <np id="3292_1" min="plane">the plane</np> be moving in a straight line or on a curved path ? What general direction will the plane be traveling in ?
A1:the plane will move in a curved path due to its velocity and the force of the wind

A:<p id = "3292_2" refid = "3292_1">it</p> will move in a straight line . newtons first law applies

INSTANCE: 2098
PROBLEM:A rocket pushes a meteor with constant force . Assume that the meteor is initially at rest and is far enough away from the sun and the planets to neglect gravity . How will the meteor move ?
H1:Please begin by briefly answering the above question . After briefly answering the above question , please go on to explain your answer in as much detail as you can .
A1:The meteor will undergo a constant acceleration . Newton 's Second Law says that the net force in one direction is equal to the mass of the object times the acceleration in that direction . Therefore , if there is a force then there is an acceleration
Q:Given that the meteor starts at rest and then has a constant acceleration , what else can you say about the meteor 's motion ?
A:<np id="2098_1" min="meteor">The meteor</np> will continue to accelerate until the rocket stops pushing <p id = "2098_2" refid = "2098_1">it</p> .

INSTANCE: 3344
PROBLEM:A sled is coasting along a frozen pond at a constant velocity toward the west . Suddenly , a strong crosswind starts to blow and exerts a constant force on the sled in the southern direction .
H4:Describe the subsequent motion of the sled . While this wind is blowing , would the sled be moving in a straight line , or would it have a curved path ? Please begin by briefly answering the above question . After briefly answering the above question , please go on to explain your answer in as much detail as you can .
A4:The sled will move in a curved path to the southwest . The only force acting on the sled is the wind , so it will have an acceleration only in the soutern direction .
H3:What principle can be applied when analyzing motion in perpendicular directions such as horizontal and vertical directions ?
A3:The decompostion principle
H2:Why is the decomposition principle relevant to this situation ?
A2:The sled 's motion is in two directions , the west and the south , but those directions of motion can be analyzed independently .
H1:Can you identify a Physics law or principle that applies to this situation ?
A1:Newton 's second law states that net force equals mass times acceleration .
Q:Good job ! What does <np id="3344_1" min="law">Newton 's second Law of motion</np> say ?
A:<p id = "3344_2" refid = "3344_1">It</p> says that net force equals mass times acceleration .

INSTANCE: 3513
PROBLEM:Tim is practicing his air hockey skills by taking shots at an unguarded goal . He hits a frictionless puck so it moves very fast directly towards the goal . His little brother Sam , standing on the side of the table , quickly nudges the puck as it passes the center of the table . The nudge is perpendicular to the original path of the puck .
H13:With this kind of nudge , could the puck 's new path ever be perpendicular to its original path ?
A13:No
H12:Let me try again . Which principle can be applied when the motion of an object is complex , for instance , it can be thought of as motion in two perpendicular dimensions ?
A12:decomposition
H11:How does the decomposition principle apply to this situation ?
A11:the is complex motion
H10:In order for the puck 's new path to be completely perpendicular to its original path toward the goal , the puck 's component of velocity in the direction of the goal would have to change to zero . Newton 's laws tells us that a component of net force in the opposite direction from the goal would be necessary to reduce the puck 's component of velocity in the direction of the goal . Since we assume the ice to be frictionless and ignore air resistance , and since Sam 's nudge is perpendicular to the puck 's original path , there are no forces that could change the puck 's component of velocity in the direction of the goal . How does the decomposition principle apply to this situation ?
A10:It allows us to seperate the original velocity from the nudge
H9:Let me try again . We will first analyze the puck 's motion in the direction of the goal , and then __ _ _ _ analyze the puck 's motion in the perpendicular direction . Then , we will __ _ _ _ the information about the puck 's motions in the direction of the goal and in the perpendicular direction to determine the puck 's path .
A9:separately combine
H8:Can you articulate the definition or principle that is most relevant to this problem ?
A8:the decomposition principle
H7:Let me try again . Which of Newton 's laws is most relevant to this situation ?
A7:second
H6:True , however Newton 's first law is even more relevant to this situation . What does Newton 's first law say ?
A6:that when the net force on a object is zero , it wil either remain at rest or move in a straight line at constant velocity
H5:How does Newton 's first law apply to the puck 's motion in the direction of the goal ?
A5:the puck is originally moving at a constant velocity towards the goal
H4:Let me try again . After Tim hits the puck toward the goal , are there any forces acting on the puck along the direction of the goal ?
A4:no
H3:Right ! What is the component of the net force on the puck along the direction of the goal ?
A3:zero
H2:Good job ! Now let 's see if you can answer my original question in a complete sentence . How does Newton 's first law apply to the puck 's motion in the direction of the goal ?
A2:there is no net force acting on the puck as it moves towards the goal , so its velocity is constant and its path is straight
H1:After Tim hits the puck toward the goal , there are __ _ _ _ forces acting on the puck along the direction of the goal . Thus , the component of the net force on the puck along the direction of the goal is __ _ __ , and Newton 's first law applies . Newton 's first law tells us that the puck 's velocity along the direction of the goal is __ _ __ .
A1:zero zero constant
Q:How does Newton 's first law apply to the puck 's motion perpendicular to the direction of the goal ?
A:the net force on <np id="3513_1" min="puck">the puck</np> in that direct is zero , so <p id = "3513_2" refid = "3513_1">it</p> will move in a perpendicular path with a constnant velocity

INSTANCE: 1713
PROBLEM:To rescue a child who has fallen down a well , rescue workers fasten him to a rope , the other end of which is then reeled in by a machine . The rope pulls the child straight upward at steady speed . How does the amount of tension in the rope compare to the downward force of gravity acting on the child ?
H8:Please begin by briefly answering the above question . After briefly answering the above question , please go on to explain your answer in as much detail as you can .
A8:The amount of tension is greater than gravity which allows for the child to be pulled out of the well .
H7:Remember that tension and downward force of gravity are both vectors . In order for two vectors to be equal , the magnitude and the direction have to be the same . In this case , the tension is upward and gravity is downward . The MAGNITUDES of these vectors can be equal , but the vectors cannot be equal . What does Newton 's first law say about an object 's motion and net force ?
A7:an object in motion will stay in motion in a straight line at a constant velocity until a force acts upon it
H6:What can you say about the net force on the kid ?
A6:the net force on the kid is moving him with a constant velocity in a straight line upward because the tension is greater than his weight
H5:Remember than according to Newton ?s 2nd Law , an imbalance of forces ( or a non-zero net force ) causes an object to accelerate . While its true that in order for the child to start moving , there needs to be an imbalance of forces , in this case we are asking about a moment when the child is already moving and is moving at a constant velocity . What can you say about the net force on the kid ?
A5:it is balanced to zero
H4:Perfect ! Which forces balance out in this case ?
A4:the tension and gravity
H3:What can you say about the amounts of the tension in the rope pulling the child and the force of gravity pulling the child downwards ?
A3:the amount of tension is greater than the force of gravity when he is being pulled
H2:Let me try again . What did we find about the net force on the kid based on Newton 's first principle ?
A2:it was equal to zero so the two forces are equivalent
H1:What are the forces acting on the child and which combine in a net forces of zero ?
A1:the tension of the rope and gravity
Q:Well done ! So , how what can you say about <np id="1713_1" min="amounts">the amounts of the tension in the rope and gravity on the child</np> ?
A:<p id = "1713_2" refid = "1713_1">they </p> are equal to zero

INSTANCE: 2095
PROBLEM:A rocket pushes a meteor with constant force . Assume that the meteor is initially at rest and is far enough away from the sun and the planets to neglect gravity . How will the meteor move ?
H3:Please begin by briefly answering the above question . After briefly answering the above question , please go on to explain your answer in as much detail as you can .
A3:The meteor will move at a constant acceleration from rest since there are no other forces acting on it .
H2:Can you articulate Newton 's second law ?
A2:Acceleration exists when a force acts on an object . It also deals with equilibrium .
H1:Yes . We already assessed that : The second law is relevant because the problem describes a non-zero NET force , which is the push from the rocket , being applied on an object , which is the meteor in this case . What does Newton 's second law say about net force , mass , and acceleration ?
A1:The larger the mass , the larger the force needs to be to move the mass with acceleration . Force equals mass times acceleration
Q:Given that the meteor starts at rest and then has a constant acceleration , what else can you say about <np id="2095_1" min="meteor">the meteor</np> 's motion ?
A:<p id = "2095_2" refid = "2095_1">It</p> has an increasing velocity .
