#HISTORY:100
INSTANCE: 1
PROBLEM: A basketball player is dribbling a basketball (continuously bouncing the ball off the ground).
H2:What forces are acting on the ball when it is moving upward and it is midway between the player's hand and the ground? Describe the motion of the ball at that moment.
A2:there is the force of gravity and the force of the ground pushing the ball up
H1:Can you articulate a law of physics which is relevant to this problem?
A1:newtons second law of motion
Q: Perfect! What does Newton's second law say?
A: for every <np id="1_1" min="force">force</np> , there is another equal force to counteract <p id="1_2" refid="1_1">it</p>
-------------------
INSTANCE: 2
PROBLEM: A basketball player is dribbling a basketball (continuously bouncing the ball off the ground).
H9:What forces are acting on the ball when it is moving upward and it is midway between the player's hand and the ground? Describe the motion of the ball at that moment.
A9:there is the force of gravity and the force of the ground pushing the ball up
H8:Can you articulate a law of physics which is relevant to this problem?
A8:newtons second law of motion
H7:Perfect! What does Newton's second law say?
A7:for every force, there is another equal force to counteract it
H6:Newton's second law says that acceleration equals ____  _____ divided by _____.
A6:mass times volume divided by time
H5:Because it is a vector, acceleration provides what two types of information?
A5:direction and magnitude
H4:What does Newton's second law tell you about the acceleration of the ball?
A4:the direction and magnitude
H3:Yes. We already assessed that: Acceleration is a vector.  Both the direction and magnitude of the acceleration matter. Since gravity is the only force acting on the ball, the direction of the net force on the ball is _____.
A3:down
H2:Right! Since the direction of the net force on the ball is downward, what does Newton's second law say about the direction of the ball's acceleration?
A2:which way up or down
H1:Since <np id="2_1" min="velocity">the  ball's velocity</np> is upward and its acceleration is downward, what is happening to the ball's velocity?
A1:increasing
Q: Your answer is a little too short. Can you please elaborate?
A: <p id="2_2" refid="2_1">it</p> is increasing
-------------------
INSTANCE: 3
PROBLEM: A basketball player is dribbling a basketball (continuously bouncing the ball off the ground).
Q: What forces are acting on <np id="3_1" min="ball">the ball</np> when it is moving upward and it is midway between the player's hand and the ground? Describe the motion of the ball at that moment.
A: gravity is pulling down while <p id="3_2" refid="3_1" comments="actually the ball's">its</p> velocity is pushing up
-------------------
INSTANCE: 4
PROBLEM: A basketball player is dribbling a basketball (continuously bouncing the ball off the ground).
H1:What forces are acting on the ball when it is moving upward and it is midway between the player's hand and the ground? Describe the motion of the ball at that moment.
A1:gravity is pulling down while its velocity is pushing up
Q: Right! Does any other force act on <np id="4_1" min="ball">the ball</np> besides gravity?
A: The velocity with which <p id="4_2" refid="4_2">it</p> bounced off the ground
-------------------
INSTANCE: 5
PROBLEM: A basketball player is dribbling a basketball (continuously bouncing the ball off the ground).
H2:What forces are acting on the ball when it is moving upward and it is midway between the player's hand and the ground? Describe the motion of the ball at that moment.
A2:gravity is pulling down while its velocity is pushing up
H1:Right! Does any other force act on <np id="5_1" min="ball">the ball</np> besides gravity?
A1:The velocity with which it bounced off the ground
Q: Let's take a closer look at my previous question.
A: <p id="5_2" refid="5_1">Its</p> velocity
-------------------
INSTANCE: 6
PROBLEM: A basketball player is dribbling a basketball (continuously bouncing the ball off the ground).
H7:What forces are acting on the ball when it is moving upward and it is midway between the player's hand and the ground? Describe the motion of the ball at that moment.
A7:gravity is pulling down while its velocity is pushing up
H6:Right! Does any other force act on the ball besides gravity?
A6:The velocity with which it bounced off the ground
H5:Let's take a closer look at my previous question.
A5:Its velocity
H4:_____ is the _____ force acting on the ball.
A4:Gravity, only
H3:Can you articulate a law of physics which is relevant to this problem?
A3:Newtons First Law
H2:Let me try again. Which of Newton's laws is most relevant to this situation?
A2:Newtons second law
H1:Right! What does Newton's second law say?
A1:The acceleration of an object as produced by a net force is directly proportional to the magnitude of the net force, in the same direction as the net force, and inversely proportional to the mass of the object.
Q: What does Newton's second law tell you about <np id="6_1" min="acceleration">the acceleration of the ball</np>?
A: <p id="6_2" refid="*6_1">It</p> is accelerating downward
-------------------

A3:f=ma

A1:magnitude and direction

A4:The forces acting on the ball are gravity, normal force, and air resistance.

A3:No

INSTANCE: 9
PROBLEM: A basketball player is dribbling a basketball (continuously bouncing the ball off the ground).
H9:What forces are acting on the ball when it is moving upward and it is midway between the player's hand and the ground? Describe the motion of the ball at that moment.
A9:The forces acting on the ball are gravity, normal force, and air resistance.
H8:Can you articulate a law of physics which is relevant to this problem?
A8:No
H7:Let me try again. Which of Newton's laws is most relevant to this situation?
A7:Newton's 1st law
H6:Which of Newton's laws relates the acceleration of an object to the net force acting on the object and the object's mass?
A6:Newton's third law
H5:What does Newton's second law say?
A5:I don't know
H4:Newton's second law says that acceleration equals ____  _____ divided by _____.
A4:I don't know
H3:Because it is a vector, acceleration provides what two types of information?
A3:Direction and magnitude
H2:What does Newton's second law tell you about the acceleration of the ball?
A2:The acceleration equals the net force divided by the mass
H1:Yes. We already assessed that: In its form most relevant to this situation, Newton's second law says that ACCELERATION equals NET FORCE divided by MASS. Since gravity is the only force acting on the ball, the direction of the net force on the ball is _____.
A1:Down
Q: Perfect! Since the direction of the net force on the ball is downward, what does Newton's second law say about <np id="9_1" min="acceleration">the direction of the ball's acceleration </np>?
A: <p id="9_2" refid="9_1">It</p> will be down

A6:the net force applied to a body produces a proportional acceleration

INSTANCE: 20
PROBLEM: A basketball player is dribbling a basketball (continuously bouncing the ball off the ground).
H2:What forces are acting on the ball when it is moving upward and it is midway between the player's hand and the ground? Describe the motion of the ball at that moment.
A2:Gravity is the only force acting on the ball. Gravity is acting on the ball downward. The ball is decelerating up word due to gravity.
H1:Can you articulate a law of physics which is relevant to this problem?
A1:When in mid air the only force acting on an object is gravity because gravity is constant.
Q: Yes. We already assessed that: GRAVITY is the ONLY force acting on the ball. Which of Newton's laws is most relevant to this situation?
A: <np id="20_1" min="object">an object</np> will remain in constant motion unless an alternate force is acting on <p id="20_2" refid="20_1">it</p> .

INSTANCE: 21
PROBLEM: A basketball player is dribbling a basketball (continuously bouncing the ball off the ground).
H3:What forces are acting on the ball when it is moving upward and it is midway between the player's hand and the ground? Describe the motion of the ball at that moment.
A3:Gravity is the only force acting on the ball. Gravity is acting on the ball downward. The ball is decelerating up word due to gravity.
H2:Can you articulate a law of physics which is relevant to this problem?
A2:When in mid air the only force acting on an object is gravity because gravity is constant.
H1:Yes. We already assessed that: GRAVITY is the ONLY force acting on the ball. Which of Newton's laws is most relevant to this situation?
A1:an object will remain in constant motion unless an alternate force is acting on it.
Q: Let's get back to my previous question and try to answer it more precisely.
A: <np id="21_1" min="ball">The ball</np> is decelerating due to the constant force of gravity . If gravity were not constant <p id="21_2" refid="21_1">it</p> would go on forever .

A4:an object will remain in constant motion unless an alternate force is acting on it.

A3:The ball is decelerating due to the constant force of gravity. If gravity were not constant it would go on forever.

A2:Force is equal to mass times the acceleration.

H3:Let me try again. Since the ball's downward acceleration is in the opposite direction of it's upward velocity, the ball is _____ down.
A3:it is decelerating due to the force of gravity
H2:Can you articulate a law of physics which is relevant to this problem?
A2:Net force is equal to the mass times the acceleration
H1:Because it is a vector, acceleration provides what two types of information?
A1:magnitude and direction
Q: What does Newton's second law tell you about the acceleration of <np id="26_1" min="ball">the ball</np>?
A: <p id="26_2" refid="*26_1">it</p> is decelerating because the net force is downwards
-------------------
INSTANCE: 27
PROBLEM: A basketball player is dribbling a basketball (continuously bouncing the ball off the ground).
H14:What forces are acting on the ball when it is moving upward and it is midway between the player's hand and the ground? Describe the motion of the ball at that moment.
A14:Gravity is the only force acting on the ball. Gravity is acting on the ball downward. The ball is decelerating up word due to gravity.
H13:Can you articulate a law of physics which is relevant to this problem?
A13:When in mid air the only force acting on an object is gravity because gravity is constant.
H12:Yes. We already assessed that: GRAVITY is the ONLY force acting on the ball. Which of Newton's laws is most relevant to this situation?
A12:an object will remain in constant motion unless an alternate force is acting on it.
H11:Let's get back to my previous question and try to answer it more precisely.
A11:The ball is decelerating due to the constant force of gravity. If gravity were not constant it would go on forever.
H10:Which of Newton's laws relates the acceleration of an object to the net force acting on the object and the object's mass?
A10:Force is equal to mass times the acceleration.
H9:Because it is a vector, acceleration provides what two types of information?
A9:speed and direction
H8:What does Newton's second law tell you about the acceleration of the ball?
A8:it is directly related to the mass of the object

A7:downward
H6:Great! Since the direction of the net force on the ball is downward, what does Newton's second law say about the direction of the ball's acceleration?
A6:it is decelerating because the net force is downward
H5:Since the ball's velocity is upward and its acceleration is downward, what is happening to the ball's velocity?
A5:it is decreasing.
H4:Let me try again. Since the ball's downward acceleration is in the opposite direction of it's upward velocity, the ball is _____ down.
A4:it is decelerating due to the force of gravity
H3:Can you articulate a law of physics which is relevant to this problem?
A3:Net force is equal to the mass times the acceleration
H2:Because it is a vector, acceleration provides what two types of information?
A2:magnitude and direction
H1:What does Newton's second law tell you about the acceleration of the ball?
A1:it is decelerating because the net force is downwards
Q: Excellent! Since the direction of the net force on the ball is downward, what does Newton's second law say about <np id="27_1" min="direction" > the direction of the ball's acceleration </np>?
A: <p id="27_2" refid="27_1">it</p> would be downward

PROBLEM: A basketball player is dribbling a basketball (continuously bouncing the ball off the ground).
H8:What forces are acting on the ball when it is moving upward and it is midway between the player's hand and the ground? Describe the motion of the ball at that moment.
A8:gravity is pulling it down
H7:Perfect! Does any other force act on the ball besides gravity?
A7:the applied force of the player's hand
H6:Let's come back to the question before and look for a more precise answer.
A6:no
H5:Can you articulate a law of physics which is relevant to this problem?
A5:the law of gravitational pull
H4:Let me try again. Which of Newton's laws is most relevant to this situation?
A4:the second law which states that gravity is acting on anything in free fall
H3:Bravo! What does Newton's second law say?
A3:free fall
H2:Newton's second law says that acceleration equals ____  _____ divided by _____.
A2:force mass
H1:Because it is a vector, acceleration provides what two types of information?
A1:magnitude and direction
Q: What does Newton's second law tell you about <np id="47_1" min="acceleration">the acceleration of the ball</np>?
A: is <p id="47_2" refid="47_1">it</p> constant
-------------------

INSTANCE: 50
PROBLEM: A basketball player is dribbling a basketball (continuously bouncing the ball off the ground).
H9:What forces are acting on the ball when it is moving upward and it is midway between the player's hand and the ground? Describe the motion of the ball at that moment.
A9:the force of the floor on the ball is causing an elastic collisions and propells the ball upward with a decreasing accelleration
H8:Since the ball is not touching the floor, the floor cannot exert any contact force on the ball during this time.  The problem refers to the period of time when the ball is midway between the floor and the player's hand.  There are no contact forces on the ball during this period of time. What downward force does the Earth exert on the ball?
A8:gravity
H7:Can you articulate a law of physics which is relevant to this problem?
A7:an object in motion will remain in constant motion until acted on by an unbalanced force
H6:Even though the ball is not touching anything during this time, there is a force acting on the ball. Can you articulate a law of physics which is relevant to this problem?
A6:gravity
H5:Let me try again. Which of Newton's laws is most relevant to this situation?
A5:the first
H4:Which of Newton's laws relates the acceleration of an object to the net force acting on the object and the object's mass?
A4:third
H3:What does Newton's second law say?
A3:idk
H2:Newton's second law says that acceleration equals ____  _____ divided by _____.
A2:force mass
H1:Because it is a vector, acceleration provides what two types of information?
A1:magnitude and direction
Q: What does Newton's second law tell you about <np id="50_1" min="acceleration">the acceleration of the ball</np>?
A: <p id="50_2" refid="50_1">it</p> is force of gravity divided by the mass of the object

INSTANCE: 55
PROBLEM: A basketball player is dribbling a basketball (continuously bouncing the ball off the ground).
H3:What forces are acting on the ball when it is moving upward and it is midway between the player's hand and the ground? Describe the motion of the ball at that moment.
A3:The force of gravity is acting on the ball when it is moving upward and it is midway between the player's hand and the ground
H2:Can you articulate a law of physics which is relevant to this problem?
A2:Newton's Second law states that if unbalanced forces are exerted on an object, then the sum of the forces will equal the product of mass times acceleration
H1:Because it is a vector, acceleration provides what two types of information?
A1:Acceleration provides a magnitude and a direction
Q: What does Newton's second law tell you about the acceleration of the ball?
A: Newton 's Second Law tells <p id="55_1" refid="0">us</p> that , since the net force exerted on the ball is unbalanced , then the acceleration of the ball will equal the net force acting on the ball divided by the mass of the ball

INSTANCE: 65
PROBLEM: A basketball player is dribbling a basketball (continuously bouncing the ball off the ground).
H10:What forces are acting on the ball when it is moving upward and it is midway between the player's hand and the ground? Describe the motion of the ball at that moment.
A10:the forces are gravity and the applied force from the ground; the motion is upward
H9:Can you articulate a law of physics which is relevant to this problem?
A9:No
H8:Let me try again. Which of Newton's laws is most relevant to this situation?
A8:1st one
H7:Which of Newton's laws relates the acceleration of an object to the net force acting on the object and the object's mass?
A7:2nd Law
H6:Perfect! What does Newton's second law say?
A6:F equals ma
H5:Newton's second law says that acceleration equals ____  _____ divided by _____.
A5:force divided by mass
H4:Because it is a vector, acceleration provides what two types of information?
A4:direction and magnitude
H3:What does Newton's second law tell you about the acceleration of the ball?
A3:The acceleration of an object depends directly upon the net force acting upon the object, and inversely upon the mass of the object. As the force acting upon an object is increased, the acceleration of the object is increased. As the mass of an object is increased, the acceleration of the object is decreased.
H2:Even though the ball is not touching anything during this time, there is a force acting on the ball. What does Newton's second law tell you about the acceleration of the ball?
A2:it is constant
H1:Let me try again. Since gravity is the only force acting on the ball, the direction of the net force on the ball is _____.
A1:downward
Q: Great! Since the direction of the net force on the ball is downward, what does Newton's second law say about <np id="65_1" min="direction">the direction of the ball's acceleration</np>?
A: <p id="65_2" refid="65_1">it</p> is downward also
-------------------

INSTANCE: 71
PROBLEM: A basketball player is dribbling a basketball (continuously bouncing the ball off the ground).
H12:What forces are acting on the ball when it is moving upward and it is midway between the player's hand and the ground? Describe the motion of the ball at that moment.
A12:Normal and gravity
H11:Can you articulate a law of physics which is relevant to this problem?
A11:Freefall
H10:Let me try again. Which of Newton's laws is most relevant to this situation?
A10:Newton's second law of motion
H9:Good job! What does Newton's second law say?
A9:The net force acting on an object will be equal to its mass times acceleration
H8:Because it is a vector, acceleration provides what two types of information?
A8:Distance and magnitude
H7:Bravo! Acceleration has information about both magnitude and what else?
A7:distance
H6:Now let's see if you can answer my original question in a complete sentence.  As a vector, acceleration provides what two types of information?
A6:Acceleration provides information about magnitude and direction
H5:What does Newton's second law tell you about the acceleration of the ball?
A5:The acceleration of the ball is equal to the net force divided by the mass
H4:Even though the ball is not touching anything during this time, there is a force acting on the ball. What does Newton's second law tell you about the acceleration of the ball?
A4:It is constant
H3:Let me try again. Since gravity is the only force acting on the ball, the direction of the net force on the ball is _____.
A3:down
H2:Well done! Since the direction of the net force on the ball is downward, what does Newton's second law say about the direction of the ball's acceleration?
A2:it is south
H1:Since gravity is the only force acting on the ball, the net force on the ball is downward, so the ball's _____ must also be _____.
A1:direction and negative
Q: Since the ball's velocity is upward and its acceleration is downward, what is happening to <np id="71_1" min="velocity">the ball's velocity</np>?
A: <p id="71_2" refid="71_1">It</p> is negative
-------------------
INSTANCE: 72
PROBLEM: A basketball player is dribbling a basketball (continuously bouncing the ball off the ground).
H8:What forces are acting on the ball when it is moving upward and it is midway between the player's hand and the ground? Describe the motion of the ball at that moment.
A8:Gravity, upward force from the ground, air resitance
H7:Can you articulate a law of physics which is relevant to this problem?
A7:The acceleration a of a body is parallel and directly proportional to the net force F acting on the body, is in the direction of the net force, and is inversely proportional to the mass m of the body, i.e., F = ma.
H6:Please use only words in your input. I am still a young tutor and I do not yet understand mathematical characters, such as +,-,*,/ or =.
A6:The acceleration of a body is parallel and directly proportional to the net force acting on the body, is in the direction of the net forcem and is inversely proportional to the mass of the body
H5:Because it is a vector, acceleration provides what two types of information?
A5:Direction
H4:Let me try again. Because acceleration is a vector, the information about the amount or quantity of acceleration is contained in the _____ of the acceleration.
A4:angle
H3:Acceleration has information about both magnitude and what else?
A3:and direction
H2:Right! Now let's see if you can answer my original question in a complete sentence.  As a vector, acceleration provides what two types of information?
A2:direction and magnitude
H1:What does Newton's second law tell you about the acceleration of the ball?
A1:The acceleration a of a body is parallel and directly proportional to the net force   acting on the body, is in the direction of the net force, and is inversely proportional to the mass of the body
Q: Even though <np id="72_1" min="ball">the ball</np> is not touching anything during this time, there is a force acting on the ball. What does Newton's second law tell you about the acceleration of the ball?
A: a force acted upon <p id="72_2" refid="72_1">it</p> so <p id="72_3" refid="72_1">it</p> is moving in the direction that <p id="72_4" refid="72_1">it</p> was acted upon

A6:The acceleration a of a body is parallel and directly proportional to the net force  acting on the body, is in the direction of the net force, and is inversely proportional to the mass  of the body

A5:direction, downward

A4:Gravity, the ball is moving upwards

A3:Newtowns second law

A: The ball is in constant acceleration due to the force applied on <p id="73_2" refid="73_1">it</p>

A8:When an object has a force applied to it, its velocity changes.

A6:Magnitude and Direction

A5:It is constant.

A4:It's negative.

A3:It is positive?

A2:It is positive.

A1:acceleration. downard.

A: <p id="92_2" refid="92_1">It</p> is slowing down .

INSTANCE: 1352
PROBLEM:A mover pushes a desk with constant velocity v0 across a carpeted floor . Suddenly , the mover stops pushing . What can you say about the motion of the desk after the mover stops pushing ? Explain why .
H2:Please begin by briefly answering the above question . After briefly answering the above question , please go on to explain your answer in as much detail as you can .
A2:The force of friction between the carpet and the desk will cause an acceleration that opposes motion . This force of friction will put in work over a distance that will eventually transfer all kenetic energy put into the system by the work of the mover , since friction is a nonconservative force , but with more relevance to Newton 's laws , Neewton 's second law states that an object has an acceleration that is equal to the net force divided by the object 's mass , so with the force of gravity and natural force in equilibrium , the only force without an equal and opposite counterpart acting upon the desk will be the force of friction which will cause the negative acceleration in the the direction opposing motion .
H1:Which Newton 's law could be useful for solving this problem and why ?
A1:his second , 2nd , number 2
Q:Let me try again . Which of Newton 's laws describes forces acting on an object , such as a desk , while moving with constant velocity ?
A:<np id="1352_1" min="Newton">Newton 's</np> 1st , first , number 1 law describes that objects with a constant velocity must have a net force of zero , but in this situation , the desk is not moving with a constant velocity so <p id = "1352_2" refid = "1352_1" >his</p> second , 2nd , number 2 law is more relevant .

A:the speed of the falling piano will remain constant according to Newton 's First Law which states that <np id="484_1" min="object">an object</np> at rest will remain in motion in a straight line at constant velocity unless there 's another force acting on <p id = "484_2" refid = "484_1">it</p> , and in this case , gravity is the only force

INSTANCE: 1652
PROBLEM:To rescue a child who has fallen down a well , rescue workers fasten him to a rope , the other end of which is then reeled in by a machine . The rope pulls the child straight upward at steady speed . How does the amount of tension in the rope compare to the downward force of gravity acting on the child ?
H11:Please begin by briefly answering the above question . After briefly answering the above question , please go on to explain your answer in as much detail as you can .
A11:The tension in the rope is greater than the downward force of gravity on the child .
H10:Remember than according to Newton ?s 2nd Law , an imbalance of forces ( or a non-zero net force ) causes an object to accelerate . While its true that in order for the child to start moving , there needs to be an imbalance of forces , in this case we are asking about a moment when the child is already moving and is moving at a constant velocity . What does Newton 's first law say about an object 's motion and net force ?
A10:an object in motion stays in motion at a constant speed in a straight line unless acted upon by an unbalanced force
H9:What can you say about the net force on the kid ?
A9:The net force is upward because the tension in the rope is greater than the force of gravity downward .
H8:Remember that tension and downward force of gravity are both vectors . In order for two vectors to be equal , the magnitude and the direction have to be the same . In this case , the tension is upward and gravity is downward . The MAGNITUDES of these vectors can be equal , but the vectors cannot be equal . What can you say about the net force on the kid ?
A8:It is upward .
H7:Let me try again . What does Newton 's first law tell you about the net force on an object , in this case the kid , when the object moves with constant velocity ?
A7:Tension is greater thean gravity
H6:Which forces balance out in this case ?
A6:none
H5:Since the child is being raised straight upward at a constant speed , the __ _ _ _ _ force on the child is __ _ _ _ _ _ and all the forces __ _ _ __ .
A5:non-zero tension poop
H4:What can you say about the amounts of the tension in the rope pulling the child and the force of gravity pulling the child downwards ?

INSTANCE: 647
PROBLEM:A parachutist is descending vertically at a constant speed of 2 meters per second .
H10:What is the net force on her ? What are the forces that add up to make the net force ?
A10:force of air resistance is upwards and the force of gravity is downwards . The net force is downwards that is why the person continues to fall
H9:Which of Newton 's laws can be applied in this situation ?
A9:net force is equal to the mass times that acceleration
H8:Which of Newton 's laws can be applied in this situation ?
A8:net force is equal to the mass times that acceleration
H7:Yes . We already assessed that : Newton 's first law says that if the net force on an object is ZERO the object is either AT REST (zero velocity ) OR moves with a CONSTANT velocity in a STRAIGHT LINE. Zero net force could be the result of no force at all acting on an object or the result of BALANCED forces ( balanced forces cancel each other out by acting in opposite directions ) . Which of Newton 's laws describes motion of objects with constant velocity ?
A7:an object will remain in motion unless an alternate force is acting on it
H6:Why does Newton 's first law apply to this situation ?
A6:Because it has a netforce downwards so it falls downwards
H5:The first law applies because the parachutist moves with __ _ _ _ _ _ __velocity .
A5:constant
H4:How can you apply Newton 's 1st law to the parachutist ?
A4:it acts as a constant resistance to the force of gravity therefore the person falls at a constant velocity
H3:Yes . We already assessed that : Newton 's first law says that if the net force on an object is ZERO the object is either AT REST (zero velocity ) OR moves with a CONSTANT velocity in a STRAIGHT LINE. Zero net force could be the result of no force at all acting on an object or the result of BALANCED forces ( balanced forces cancel each other out by acting in opposite directions ) . According to Newton 's first law , what is the net force on an object moving at constant speed ?
A3:The net force is downwards
H2:Since the parachutist is moving at a constant speed , the net force on her must be __ _ _ __ .
A2:zero
H1:So , what can you say briefly about the net force on the parachutist ?
A1:the net force acting on the parachutist is zero because they are moving at a constant velocity .

INSTANCE: 2493
PROBLEM:Susan is riding her bike with constant velocity to school while holding an apple . On the way , she accidentally drops the apple . Assume there is no air resistance .
H2:Where does that apple land relative to Susan along the road ? Please begin by briefly answering the above question . After briefly answering the above question , please go on to explain your answer in as much detail as you can .
A2:behind her
H1:Let me try again . Which principle can be applied when the motion of an object is complex , for instance , it can be thought of as motion in two perpendicular dimensions ?
A1:the horizontal and vertical directions are independent of each other
Q:What can you say about Susan 's horizontal velocity and the apple 's horizontal velocity after Susan drops <np id="2493_1" min="apple">the apple</np> ?
A:<p id = "2493_2" refid = "2493_1">it</p> will move vertically towards the Earth , and also <p id = "2493_3" refid = "2493_1">it</p> moves horizontally because <p id = "2493_4" refid = "2493_1">it</p> has a horizontal velocity at the moment <p id = "2493_5" refid = "2493_1">it</p> leaves Susan 's hand . The decomposition principle says that the analyses of forces and motion along two perpendicular directions , such as horizontal and vertical , can be done independently . That is , Newton 's laws can be applied in each direction separately , without affecting the analysis of the other perpendicular direction .

A2:The balls will reach their highest points at the same time because the acceleration is the same for both balls .

INSTANCE: 3495
PROBLEM:Tim is practicing his air hockey skills by taking shots at an unguarded goal . He hits a frictionless puck so it moves very fast directly towards the goal . His little brother Sam , standing on the side of the table , quickly nudges the puck as it passes the center of the table . The nudge is perpendicular to the original path of the puck .
H20:With this kind of nudge , could the puck 's new path ever be perpendicular to its original path ?
A20:yes
H19:In order for the puck 's new path to be completely perpendicular to its original path toward the goal , the puck 's component of velocity in the direction of the goal would have to change to zero . Newton 's laws tells us that a component of net force in the opposite direction from the goal would be necessary to reduce the puck 's component of velocity in the direction of the goal . Since we assume the ice to be frictionless and ignore air resistance , and since Sam 's nudge is perpendicular to the puck 's original path , there are no forces that could change the puck 's component of velocity in the direction of the goal . Which principle can be applied when the motion of an object is complex , for instance , it can be thought of as motion in two perpendicular dimensions ?
A19:It would have to be at a 45 degree angle and equal force
H18:The decomposition principle says that the analyses of forces and motion along two __ _ _ _ directions , such as horizontal and vertical , can be done __ _ __ .
A18:different separately
H17:How does the decomposition principle apply to this situation ?
A17:The force of the nudge accelerates the puck perpendicularly , and independent of its original velocity .
H16:Perhaps . We will first analyze the puck 's motion in the direction of the goal , and then __ _ _ _ analyze the puck 's motion in the perpendicular direction . Then , we will __ _ _ _ the information about the puck 's motions in the direction of the goal and in the perpendicular direction to determine the puck 's path .
A16:asds
H15:Can you articulate the definition or principle that is most relevant to this problem ?
A15:Newton 's second law
H14:True , however Newton 's first law is even more relevant to this situation . What does Newton 's first law say ?
A14:objects do not accelerate unless a force is enacted on them
H13:How does Newton 's first law apply to the puck 's motion in the direction of the goal ?
A13:Its original velocity remains unchanged as no net force is enacted .
H12:Great ! What is the component of the net force on the puck along the direction of the goal ?
A12:zero
H11:Perfect ! Now let 's see if you can answer my original question in a complete sentence . How does Newton 's first law apply to the puck 's motion in the direction of the goal ?
A11:It remains unchanged until a force is acted

Thus , the component of the net force on the puck along the direction of the goal is __ _ __ , and Newton 's first law applies . A10:no zero constnat
H9:How does Newton 's first law apply to the puck 's motion perpendicular to the direction of the goal ?
A9:awr rf
H8:Let me try again . After Sam nudges the puck perpendicular to the direction of the goal , are there any forces acting on the puck perpendicular to the direction of the goal ?
A8:no
H7:Good job ! What is the component of the net force on the puck perpendicular to the direction of the goal ?
A7:zero
H6:Right ! Now let 's see if you can answer my original question in a complete sentence . How does Newton 's first law apply to the puck 's motion perpendicular to the direction of the goal ?
A6:The puck does not change velocities until a force is exerted .
H5:After Sam nudges the puck perpendicular to the direction of the goal , there are __ _ _ _ forces acting on the puck perpendicular to the direction of the goal . A5:no zero constant
H4:After Sam 's nudge , the puck has constant components of velocity in BOTH the direction of the goal and perpendicular to the direction of the goal . So could the puck 's new path ever be completely perpendicular to the direction of the goal ?
A4:no
H3:Let me try again . How would you describe the angle between the puck 's new path and the direction of the goal ?
A3:No, because the original horizontal velocity must be cancelled in order to produce a perpendicular motion .
H2:What principle can be applied when analyzing motion in perpendicular directions such as horizontal and vertical directions ?
A2:The decomposition principle allows you to treat the vertical and horizontal components of the velocity as separate entities .
H1:How does the decomposition principle apply to this situation ?
A1:The force exerted by the nudge does not change the original horizontal velocity component , because it only affects the force magnitude perpendicular to the original .
Q:Yes . We already assessed that : If a component of the net force on an object is zero , the object has a constant component of velocity in that direction . INSTANCE: 2117
PROBLEM:A rocket pushes a meteor with constant force . Assume that the meteor is initially at rest and is far enough away from the sun and the planets to neglect gravity . How will the meteor move ?
H3:Please begin by briefly answering the above question . After briefly answering the above question , please go on to explain your answer in as much detail as you can .
A3:It is going to accelerate at a constant rate . Because there is no other forces than the rocket , it is going to move for ever .
H2:Can you articulate Newton 's second law ?
A2:When unequal forces acting onto a object , it is moving into the direction of the bigger force .
H1:Yes . We already assessed that : The second law is relevant because the problem describes a non-zero NET force , which is the push from the rocket , being applied on an object , which is the meteor in this case . What does Newton 's second law say about net force , mass , and acceleration ?
A1:The acceleration a of a body is parallel and directly proportional to the net force F acting on the body , is in the direction of the net force , and is inversely proportional to the mass m of the body .
Q:Given that the meteor starts at rest and then has a constant acceleration , what else can you say about <np id="2117_1" min="meteor">the meteor</> 's motion ?
A:<p id = "2117_2" refid = "2117_1">it</p> is in a straight line and the meteor will not stop .

INSTANCE: 3320
PROBLEM:A sled is coasting along a frozen pond at a constant velocity toward the west . Suddenly , a strong crosswind starts to blow and exerts a constant force on the sled in the southern direction .
H3:Describe the subsequent motion of the sled . While this wind is blowing , would the sled be moving in a straight line , or would it have a curved path ? Please begin by briefly answering the above question . After briefly answering the above question , please go on to explain your answer in as much detail as you can .
A3:It would follow a curved path , diagonally moving along the force of the wind .
H2:What principle can be applied when analyzing motion in perpendicular directions such as horizontal and vertical directions ?
A2:Decomposition principle can be applied to this situation .
H1:Why is the decomposition principle relevant to this situation ?
A1:The decomposition principle can be used to analyze the magnitude of force in the x and y directions independently of each other .
Q:Yes . We already assessed that : The decomposition principle says that the analyses of forces and motion along two perpendicular directions , such as horizontal and vertical , can be done independently . That is , Newton 's laws can be applied in each direction separately , without affecting the analysis of the other perpendicular direction . What are two directions along which the sled will move after the wind starts blowing ?
A:<np id="3320_1" min="force">THe force of the wind</np> pushes the sled in the y direction downward , whilst <p id = "3320_2" refid = "3320_1">its </p> previous vector remains unaltered in the x direction .

INSTANCE: 1770
PROBLEM:To rescue a child who has fallen down a well , rescue workers fasten him to a rope , the other end of which is then reeled in by a machine . The rope pulls the child straight upward at steady speed . How does the amount of tension in the rope compare to the downward force of gravity acting on the child ?
H8:Please begin by briefly answering the above question . After briefly answering the above question , please go on to explain your answer in as much detail as you can .
A8:greater than the force of gravity
H7:Remember than according to Newton ?s 2nd Law , an imbalance of forces ( or a non-zero net force ) causes an object to accelerate . While its true that in order for the child to start moving , there needs to be an imbalance of forces , in this case we are asking about a moment when the child is already moving and is moving at a constant velocity . Which of Newton 's laws is most relevant to this situation ?
A7:third
H6:Which of Newton 's laws talks about objects moving with constant velocity or on which zero net forces are being applied ?
A6:first
H5:Good job ! What does Newton 's first law say ?
A5:objects in motion will stay in motion as long as the net force is zero
H4:What can you say about the amounts of the tension in the rope pulling the child and the force of gravity pulling the child downwards ?
A4:the tension is greater than the gravity
H3:Remember that tension and downward force of gravity are both vectors . In order for two vectors to be equal , the magnitude and the direction have to be the same . In this case , the tension is upward and gravity is downward . The MAGNITUDES of these vectors can be equal , but the vectors cannot be equal . What can you say about the amounts of the tension in the rope pulling the child and the force of gravity pulling the child downwards ?
A3:the magnitude of the tension is greater than the magnitude of gravity
H2:Let me try again . What did we find about the net force on the kid based on Newton 's first principle ?
A2:the net force is not zero
H1:What are the forces acting on the child and which combine in a net forces of zero ?
A1:tension and gravity
Q:Great ! So , how what can you say about <np id="1770_1" min="amounts">the amounts of the tension in the rope and gravity on the child</np> ?
A:<p id = "1770_2" refid = "1770_1">they </p> are equal but opposite

INSTANCE: 2194
PROBLEM:A rocket pushes a meteor with constant force . Assume that the meteor is initially at rest and is far enough away from the sun and the planets to neglect gravity . How will the meteor move ?
H8:Please begin by briefly answering the above question . After briefly answering the above question , please go on to explain your answer in as much detail as you can .
A8:Due to inertia , the meteor will be slow to accelerate to the speed of the rocket , but will eventually get there . Inertia prevents the meteor from immediatly going the same speed as the rocket as soon as the rocket makes contact with meteor .
H7:Let me try again . Which of Newton 's laws relates net force and acceleration ?
A7:Newton 's 1st law
H6:Why is Newton 's second law relevant ?
A6:Inertia is a key factor in this situation . Second law is all about inertia
H5:The second law is relevant because the problem describes a non-zero __ _ _ _ _ force , which is the __ _ _ _ from the rocket , being applied on an object , which is the meteor in this case .
A5:constant
H4:Can you articulate Newton 's second law ?
A4:Yes
H3:Let me try again . What does Newton 's second law say about net force , mass , and acceleration ?
A3:Acceleration is produced when a force acts on a mass . The greater the mass , the greater the amount of force needed .
H2:Given the non-zero net force acting on the meteor , what does Newton 's second law say about the acceleration of the meteor ?
A2:It takes some time .
H1:Let me try again . According to Newton 's second law , the non-zero net force acting on the meteor will make it move with __ _ _ _ acceleration in the direction of the net force , which is the same direction as the rocket 's push .
A1:slow

A:<p id = "2194_2" refid = "2194_1">It</p> has constant acceleration

PROBLEM:A hockey puck rests in the middle of an ice rink . What forces are acting on the puck ?
H8:Please begin by briefly answering the above question . After briefly answering the above question , please go on to explain your answer in as much detail as you can .
A8:A force of gravity acts dowward on the puck , and a reactive force upward on the puck is applied by the ice .
H7:Well , if only gravity were acting on the puck vertically , the puck would not be at rest in the vertical direction but rather move with the gravitational acceleration downwards . Which one of Newton 's laws talks about objects at rest ?
A7:The first law .
H6:Bravo! Why is Newton 's first law relevant to solving this problem ?
A6:Because the puck is not moving
H5:Can you articulate Newton 's first law ?
A5:An object at rest remains at rest , and an object in motion remains in motion at a constant velocity unless acted upon by an unbalanced force .
H4:According to Newton 's first law , what can you say about the net force acting on the puck given that the puck is at rest ?
A4:Well , obviously there are either no horizontal forces acting on the puck or two equally strong horizontal forces acting on the puck , causing it to remain in place .

A3:0

A2:I already told you : a downward force of gravity , and an upward force by the ice .
H1:Let me try again . Gravity acts on the puck . However , another force must balance it such that the total or net force on the puck is zero . Can you identify the other force ?
A1:THE ICE! ! ! ! ! !

A:HOLY SHMOLY <p id = "2231_1" refid = "0">I</p> JUST SAID ALL OF THAT WORD FOR WORD

INSTANCE: 2268
PROBLEM:A hockey puck rests in the middle of an ice rink . What forces are acting on the puck ?
H1:Please begin by briefly answering the above question . After briefly answering the above question , please go on to explain your answer in as much detail as you can .
A1:Gravity and normal force are acting on the puck . The Earth 's gravity is pulling the puck downward and according to Newton 's Third Law of Motion , another force must be applied in the opposite direction to prevent the puck from accelerating downward . This balancing force is called the normal force , and is applied by the ice in an upwards direction .
Q:Which of Newton 's laws is relevant to this problem and why ?
A:The First and Third Laws are relevant . The first Law because <np id="2268_1" min="puck">the puck</np> is at rest , therefore the net force must be zero , and the third law because in order to have a zero net force , the downward force of gravity must have an equal and opposite force opposing <p id = "2268_2 " refid = "2268_1">it</p> .

INSTANCE: 2010
PROBLEM:A rocket pushes a meteor with constant force . Assume that the meteor is initially at rest and is far enough away from the sun and the planets to neglect gravity . How will the meteor move ?
H4:Please begin by briefly answering the above question . After briefly answering the above question , please go on to explain your answer in as much detail as you can .
A4:The meteor will move in the same direction as the force being applied onto it by the rocket . We know this because Newton 's first law states an object in motion or at rest will stay that way until the force acts upon it . In this case , the rocket is applying a force and therefore the object will go in that direction .
H3:Can you articulate Newton 's second law ?
A3:Newton 's second law is the net force on an object will be equal to the mass of that object times the acceleration
H2:Given the non-zero net force acting on the meteor , what does Newton 's second law say about the acceleration of the meteor ?
A2:The acceleration will be equal to the non-zero net force divided by the mass
H1:Yes . We already assessed that : Newton 's second law says that NET FORCE equals MASS times ACCELERATION. According to Newton 's second law , the non-zero net force acting on the meteor will make it move with __ _ _ _ acceleration in the direction of the net force , which is the same direction as the rocket 's push .
A1:positive

A:The net force is non-zero , so <p id = "2010_2" refid = "2010_1">it</p> is not at a constant velocity and thus will keep accelerating until the force is changed

A3:the parachutist will stay at a constant velocity of 2 meters per second unless an external force acts upon her .
H2:Yes . We already assessed that : Newton 's first law says that if the net force on an object is ZERO the object is either AT REST (zero velocity ) OR moves with a CONSTANT velocity in a STRAIGHT LINE. Zero net force could be the result of no force at all acting on an object or the result of BALANCED forces ( balanced forces cancel each other out by acting in opposite directions ) . According to Newton 's first law , what is the net force on an object moving at constant speed ?
A2:zero
H1:So , what can you say briefly about the net force on the parachutist ?
A1:it is zero .

A2:The decomposition

The net force of zero could be the result of no force at all acting on an object . However , a net force of zero could also be the result of BALANCED forces acting on the object ( balanced forces cancel each other out by acting in opposite directions ) . INSTANCE: 3274
PROBLEM:An airplane is flying on a windy day . The thrust from the plane 's engines is balanced by air resistance such that the plane has a constant component of velocity toward due south . Also , a crosswind pushes the plane with a constant velocity toward due west .
H3:Will the plane be moving in a straight line or on a curved path ? What general direction will the plane be traveling in ?
A3:straight line because of vector addition
H2:Possibly . Which principle can be applied when the motion of an object is complex , for instance , it can be thought of as motion in two perpendicular dimensions ?
A2:vector addition
H1:The decomposition principle says that the analyses of forces and motion along two __ _ _ _ directions , such as horizontal and vertical , can be done __ _ __ .
A1:different
Q:How does the decomposition principle apply to this situation ?
A:The decomposition principle says that the analyses of forces and motion along two perpendicular directions , such as horizontal and vertical , can be done independently . That is , Newton 's laws can be applied in each direction separately , without affecting the analysis of the other perpendicular direction . Whether the quarter lands in Chris 's hand depends on the relative horizontal motions of the quarter and Chris 's hand . The decomposition principle tells <p id = "3274_1" refid = "0">us</p> that the vertical direction is not relevant to the analysis of horizontal motion . Thus , no analysis of the vertical direction is needed to answer the question . The wagon , Chris , Chris 's hand , and the quarter all have the same constant horizontal component of velocity both before and after the throw . <np id="3274_1" min="quarter and Chris">The quarter and Chris</np> 's relative horizontal positions are identical as <p id = "3274_2" refid = "3274_1">they </p> have all the time equal horizontal velocities and start at the same position initially , at the moment of the throw . Since Chris 's hand and the quarter travel equal horizontal distances in equal times , the quarter will land in Chris 's hand
-------------------

INSTANCE: 2766
PROBLEM:Chris is sitting in a wagon at rest with a quarter in his hand . He closes his eyes and throws the quarter upward . After a while , the quarter lands back in his hand without Chris opening his eyes .

A6:next to him
H5:Let me try again . Which principle can be applied when the motion of an object is complex , for instance , it can be thought of as motion in two perpendicular dimensions ?
A5:horzontila
H4:The decomposition principle says that the analyses of forces and motion along two __ _ _ _ directions , such as horizontal and vertical , can be done __ _ __ .
A4:same
H3:How does the decomposition principle apply to this situation ?
A3:e decomposition principle says that the analyses of forces and motion along two perpendicular directions , such as horizontal and vertical , can be done independently . That is , Newton 's laws can be applied in each direction separately , without affecting the analysis of the other perpendicular direction .
H2:Good job ! According to the decomposition principle , whether the quarter lands in Chris 's hand depends on the relative motions of the quarter and Chris ' hand in what direction ?
A2:horzontial or vertical
H1:Whether the quarter lands in Chris 's hand depends on the relative horizontal motions of the quarter and Chris 's hand . Thus , no analysis of the __ _ _ _ direction is needed to answer the question .
A1:same
Q:What can you say about the horizontal component of the velocity of the wagon , Chris , Chris 's hand , and the quarter both before and after the throw ?
A:e decomposition principle tells <p id = "2766_1" refid = "0">us</p> that the vertical direction is not relevant to the analysis of horizontal motion

A5:Because the rocket is pushing the meteor at a constant force and a constant acceleration and is not being acted on by other forces of gravity .
H4:Why is Newton 's second law relevant to this problem ?
A4:the non-zero net force acting on the meteor will make it move with a constant acceleration in the direction of the net force
H3:Yes . We already assessed that : According to Newton 's second law , the non-zero net force acting on the meteor will make it move with constant acceleration in the direction of the net force , which is the same direction as the rocket 's push . Can you identify an object and a net force acting on that object such that you can apply Newton 's second law ?
A3:Rocket
H2:The second law is relevant because the problem describes a non-zero __ _ _ _ _ force , which is the __ _ _ _ from the rocket , being applied on an object , which is the meteor in this case .
A2:net , force
H1:Given that the meteor starts at rest and then has a constant acceleration , what else can you say about the meteor 's motion ?
A1:It moving to the left at a constant velocity

That is not the case here as the rocket exerts a constant NON-zero net force on the meteor . Given that the meteor starts at rest and then has a constant acceleration , what else can you say about the meteor 's motion ?

A: <np id = "349_1" min="Billy"> Billy<\np>'s  <np id = "349_3" min="stone"> stone <\np> will hit the water first because <p id = "349_2" refid = "349_1" >his</p> stone only has the vertical force of gravity acting upon <p id = "349_4" refid = "349_3">it</p> . Newtons second law explains that since only the force of gravity is acting upon <p id = "349_4" refid = "349_3">it</p> , <p id = "349_5" refid = "349_3">it</p> is moving at a constant downwards acceleration . INSTANCE: 1849
PROBLEM:A piano is lowered straight down from a top floor apartment by a rope and is moving at constant velocity . How does the tension in the rope compare to the downward force of gravity ?
H2:Please begin by briefly answering the above question . After briefly answering the above question , please go on to explain your answer in as much detail as you can .
A2:the tension is the rope is less than that of the downward force of gravity
H1:Remember that tension and downward force of gravity are both vectors . In order for two vectors to be equal , the magnitude and the direction have to be the same . In this case , the tension is upward and gravity is downward . The MAGNITUDES of these vectors can be equal , but the vectors cannot be equal . What does Newton 's first law say about an object 's motion and net force ?
A1:the object 's motion is downward and the net force is zero

INSTANCE: 2103
PROBLEM:A rocket pushes a meteor with constant force . Assume that the meteor is initially at rest and is far enough away from the sun and the planets to neglect gravity . How will the meteor move ?
H1:Please begin by briefly answering the above question . After briefly answering the above question , please go on to explain your answer in as much detail as you can .
A1:The object will accelerate . It will continue to accelerate because according to Newton 's 2nd law , the net force is equal to the mass times acceleration , so acceleration is equal to the net force divided by the mass . With only one force acting upon the metor ( no force opposing motion) The meteor will just continue to accelerate .
Q:Right ! Why is <np id = "2103_1" min="law"> Newton 's second law <\np> relevant ?
A:<p id = "2103_2" refid = "2103_1">It</p> states that the net force is equal to the mass times the acceleration , so with only once <np id = "2103_3" min="force">force acting on <np id = "2103_4" min="meteor">the meteor</np></np> and no force opposing <p id = "2103_5" refid = "2103_3">it</p> and the meteor 's mass constant , <p id = "2103_6" refid = "2103_4">it</p> will continie to accelerate .

INSTANCE: 3492
PROBLEM:Tim is practicing his air hockey skills by taking shots at an unguarded goal . He hits a frictionless puck so it moves very fast directly towards the goal . H9:With this kind of nudge , could the puck 's new path ever be perpendicular to its original path ?
A9:yes
H8:In order for the puck 's new path to be completely perpendicular to its original path toward the goal , the puck 's component of velocity in the direction of the goal would have to change to zero . Since we assume the ice to be frictionless and ignore air resistance , and since Sam 's nudge is perpendicular to the puck 's original path , there are no forces that could change the puck 's component of velocity in the direction of the goal . A8:It would have to be at a 45 degree angle and equal force

A7:different separately
H6:How does the decomposition principle apply to this situation ?
A6:The force of the nudge accelerates the puck perpendicularly , and independent of its original velocity .

A5:asds

A4:Newton 's second law

A3:objects do not accelerate unless a force is enacted on them

A2:Its original velocity remains unchanged as no net force is enacted .

A1:zero

A1:nder these conditions we must realize that a group of forces on an object adds up so that all the forces appear to the object as one force . INSTANCE: 1773
PROBLEM:To rescue a child who has fallen down a well , rescue workers fasten him to a rope , the other end of which is then reeled in by a machine . The rope pulls the child straight upward at steady speed . How does the amount of tension in the rope compare to the downward force of gravity acting on the child ?
H12:Please begin by briefly answering the above question . After briefly answering the above question , please go on to explain your answer in as much detail as you can .
A12:the tension is greater than the downward force
H11:Remember than according to Newton ?s 2nd Law , an imbalance of forces ( or a non-zero net force ) causes an object to accelerate . While its true that in order for the child to start moving , there needs to be an imbalance of forces , in this case we are asking about a moment when the child is already moving and is moving at a constant velocity . Which of Newton 's laws is most relevant to this situation ?
A11:second
H10:True , however Newton 's first law is even more relevant to this situation . What does Newton 's first law say ?
A10:objects in motion stay in motion and object at rest stay at rest unless acted on by an unbalanced force
H9:What can you say about the net force on the kid ?
A9:it is not zero
H8:What do you mean by "it " ? Please type only the replacement word or phrase .
A8:the net force is not zero
H7:Remember that tension and downward force of gravity are both vectors . In order for two vectors to be equal , the magnitude and the direction have to be the same . In this case , the tension is upward and gravity is downward . The MAGNITUDES of these vectors can be equal , but the vectors cannot be equal . What can you say about the net force on the kid ?
A7:it is grater in the upwards direction
H6:What do you mean by "it " ?
A6:the net force
H5:Let me try again . What does Newton 's first law tell you about the net force on an object , in this case the kid , when the object moves with constant velocity ?
A5:it is zero
H4:Excellent ! Which forces balance out in this case ?
A4:the tension
H3:Since the child is being raised straight upward at a constant speed , the __ _ _ _ _ force on the child is __ _ _ _ _ _ and all the forces __ _ _ __ .
A3:net force , zero
H2:What can you say about the amounts of the tension in the rope pulling the child and the force of gravity pulling the child downwards ?
A2:the tension is greater thn down force
H1:Let me try again . What did we find about the net force on the kid based on Newton 's first principle ?
A1:it is zero
Q:What are the forces acting on <np id = "1773_1" min="child">the child </np> and which combine in a net forces of zero ?
A:the tension and <p id = "1773_2" refid = "1773_1" >his</p> weight
-------------------
INSTANCE: 862
PROBLEM:Two balls are dropped from the same height out of a 1st story window at the same time . The red ball has four times as much mass as the green ball .
H3:How do the accelerations of the two balls due to gravity compare ?
A3:The balls will accelerate at the same magnitude .
H2:Can you state a relevant definition or principle ?
A2:Newton 's second law
H1:Let me try again . What can you say about objects near earth upon which the only force acting is the force of gravity exerted by the earth ?
A1:I do n't know
Q:When only gravity is acting on an object it is said to be in __ _ __ . All objects near the surface of the earth freefall with the same __ _ _ _ downward acceleration regardless of mass ( neglecting the affects of air resistance ) .
A:When gravity is acting on <np id = "862_1" min="object"> an object </np> <p id = "862_2" refid = "862_1">it</p> is said to be in freefall .

INSTANCE: 2998
PROBLEM:Two sisters are on a ledge over a deep swimming pool . Sue , the younger and smaller sister , takes a running start and goes straight off the ledge . Paulette , the older and larger sister , simply steps off the ledge at the same moment that Sue leaves the ledge .
H1:Which sister will hit the water first ?
A1:The decomposition principle says that the analyses of forces and motion along two perpendicular directions , such as horizontal and vertical , can be done independently . That is , Newton 's laws can be applied in each direction separately , without affecting the analysis of the other perpendicular direction . Since the problem asks which stone will hit the water first , the only important direction for us to analyze is the vertical direction . The decomposition principle tells us that we do n't really need to analyze the horizontal direction at all in this particular problem because of the question asked . When only gravity is acting on an object it is said to be in freefall . All objects near the surface of the earth freefall with the same constant downward acceleration regardless of mass ( neglecting air resistance ) . Once Sarah throws her stone , gravity is the only force acting on Sarah 's stone (ignoring air resistance ) . Once Billy drops his stone , gravity is the only force acting on Billy 's stone (ignoring air resistance ) . Thus , both stones are in freefall and have the same constant acceleration due to gravity . Since the stones have the same constant acceleration due to gravity and are released from the same height at the same time , both stones will hit the water at the same time .
Q:Bravo! Why is the decomposition principle relevant here ?
A:The decomposition principle is relevant because  <np id = "2998_1" min="apple">the apple </np> is in free fall , which means will move vertically towards the Earth , and also <p id = "2998_2" refid = "2998_1">it</p> moves horizontally because <p id = "2998_3" refid = "2998_1">it</p> has a horizontal velocity at the moment <p id = "2998_3" refid = "2998_1">it</p> leaves Susan 's hand .
-------------------

A2:Newton 's first law . You already asked this question ...

A1:The parachutist is desending at a constant velocity with a downward force of gravity and an upward force from air resistance making the net force balanced .
Q:How can you apply Newton 's 1st law to the parachutist ?
A:<p id = "775_1" refid = "0">I</p> already answered that question

INSTANCE: 3501
PROBLEM:Tim is practicing his air hockey skills by taking shots at an unguarded goal . He hits a frictionless puck so it moves very fast directly towards the goal . His little brother Sam , standing on the side of the table , quickly nudges the puck as it passes the center of the table . The nudge is perpendicular to the original path of the puck .
H4:With this kind of nudge , could the puck 's new path ever be perpendicular to its original path ?
A4:yes
H3:In order for the puck 's new path to be completely perpendicular to its original path toward the goal , the puck 's component of velocity in the direction of the goal would have to change to zero . Newton 's laws tells us that a component of net force in the opposite direction from the goal would be necessary to reduce the puck 's component of velocity in the direction of the goal . Since we assume the ice to be frictionless and ignore air resistance , and since Sam 's nudge is perpendicular to the puck 's original path , there are no forces that could change the puck 's component of velocity in the direction of the goal . Which principle can be applied when the motion of an object is complex , for instance , it can be thought of as motion in two perpendicular dimensions ?
A3:newton 's first law
H2:The decomposition principle says that the analyses of forces and motion along two __ _ _ _ directions , such as horizontal and vertical , can be done __ _ __ .
A2:perpendicular independently
H1:How does the decomposition principle apply to this situation ?
A1:it doesnt
Q:Let me try again . We will first analyze the puck 's motion in the direction of the goal , and then __ _ _ _ analyze the puck 's motion in the perpendicular direction . Then , we will __ _ _ _ the information about the puck 's motions in the direction of the goal and in the perpendicular direction to determine the puck 's path .
A:<p id = "3501_1" refid = "0">we</p> will analyze

A4:2

A2:It is constant .

H7:Please begin by briefly answering the above question . After briefly answering the above question , please go on to explain your answer in as much detail as you can .
A7:The meteor will have constant acceleration in the direction the rocket is pushing it . According to Newton 's Second Law , F=ma , and a constant force to an unchanging mass would result in constant acceleration .
H6:Please use only words in your input . I am still a young tutor and I do not yet understand mathematical characters , such as +,-,*,/ or = .
A6:The meteor will have constant acceleration in the direction the rocket is pushing it . According to Newton 's Second Law , force equals mass times acceleration , and a constant force to an unchanging mass would result in constant acceleration .

A5:Newton 's Second Law is one of the laws of motion and it explains the relationship with force and acceleration

H3:Can you articulate Newton 's second law ?
A3:Net force is proportional to acceleration and mass is inversely proportional to acceleration .
H2:Given the non-zero net force acting on the meteor , what does Newton 's second law say about the acceleration of the meteor ?
A2:the acceleration is non-zero

A1:constant

A8:they will hit the ground at the same time because they are both experiencing the same downward force of gravity and therefore the same acceleration

A7:all objects in free fall will experience the same constant downward force of gravity

A6:they are in free fall
H5:Can you state a relevant definition or principle ?
A5:all objects upon which gravity is the only force exerted are in free fall . Objects in free fall will experience the same downward force by gravity which will cause them to fall at the same speed
H4:Let me try again . What is the standard definition of acceleration ?
A4:change in speed divided by change in time
H3:How can you relate the ideas of freefall and acceleration to this situation ?
A3:objects in free fall will accelerate at the same constant rate . If both objects start at zero , they will travel at the same acceleration over the same time intervals and therefore fall at the same speeds and hit the ground at the same time
H2:Yes . We already assessed that : The balls will hit the ground at the same time . When an object is in freefall , the only force acting upon it is __ _ __ . This produces a __ _ _ _ acceleration .
A2:gravity constant

A1:they will be equal

A:When an <np id = "1086_1" min="object"> object is in free fall </np> <p id = "1086_2" refid = "1086_1">it</p> will only experience a constant downward force of gravity . This will cause the constant acceleration and will therefore make the two balls travel at equal speeds

INSTANCE: 3483
PROBLEM:Tim is practicing his air hockey skills by taking shots at an unguarded goal . He hits a frictionless puck so it moves very fast directly towards the goal . His little brother Sam , standing on the side of the table , quickly nudges the puck as it passes the center of the table . The nudge is perpendicular to the original path of the puck .
H15:With this kind of nudge , could the puck 's new path ever be perpendicular to its original path ?
A15:yes
H14:In order for the puck 's new path to be completely perpendicular to its original path toward the goal , the puck 's component of velocity in the direction of the goal would have to change to zero . Newton 's laws tells us that a component of net force in the opposite direction from the goal would be necessary to reduce the puck 's component of velocity in the direction of the goal . Since we assume the ice to be frictionless and ignore air resistance , and since Sam 's nudge is perpendicular to the puck 's original path , there are no forces that could change the puck 's component of velocity in the direction of the goal . Which principle can be applied when the motion of an object is complex , for instance , it can be thought of as motion in two perpendicular dimensions ?
A14:decomposition principle

A13:meh

INSTANCE: 3410
PROBLEM:An ice cube is sliding across a table top . There is no friction between the tabletop and the ice cube . When the cube passes a child , the child quickly pokes the ice cube . The direction of the poking force is perpendicular to the cube 's initial path .
H2:Describe the motion of the ice cube right after the poke . Would the cube be moving in a straight line , or would it have a curved path ?
A2:The decomposition principle says that the analyses of forces and motion along two perpendicular directions , such as horizontal and vertical , can be done independently . That is , Newton 's laws can be applied in each direction separately , without affecting the analysis of the other perpendicular direction . The plane 's motion along the north-south direction can be analyzed separately from the plane 's motion along the east-west direction . The result of the analysis along these two perpendicular directions is combined to determine the plane 's overall path of motion . The plane will travel in a straight line , because the combination of constant velocity components to the south and west give the plane 's path a constant slope . The plane would be moving in a straight line to the southwest , combining the plane 's components of velocity to the south and to the west .
H1:What can you say about the net force on the cube before the poke ?
A1:its zero
Q:What can you say about the net force on  <np id = "3410_1" min="cube">the cube </np> before the poke ?
A:<p id = "3410_2" refid = "3410_1">its </p> normal force balances the force of gravity
-------------------

INSTANCE: 1877
PROBLEM:A piano is lowered straight down from a top floor apartment by a rope and is moving at constant velocity . How does the tension in the rope compare to the downward force of gravity ?
H6:Please begin by briefly answering the above question . After briefly answering the above question , please go on to explain your answer in as much detail as you can .
A6:It is balanced
H5:Perhaps . What does Newton 's first law say about an object 's motion and net force ?
A5:the behavior of objects for which all existing forces are balanced
H4:Newton 's first law says that if an object moves with a constant velocity or is at rest , the net force on the object is __ _ __ .
A4:zero
H3:How does Newton 's first law apply to the piano being lowered down with constant speed ?
A3:The forces are equal or balanced or equl zero so that the object is at constant speed
H2:Remember that tension and downward force of gravity are both vectors . In order for two vectors to be equal , the magnitude and the direction have to be the same . In this case , the tension is upward and gravity is downward . The MAGNITUDES of these vectors can be equal , but the vectors cannot be equal . How does Newton 's first law apply to the piano being lowered down with constant speed ?
A2:if the forces acting upon an object are balanced , then the acceleration of that object will be 0 m/s/s . Objects at equilibrium ( the condition in which all forces balance ) will not accelerate . According to Newton , an object will only accelerate if there is a net or unbalanced force acting upon it . The presence of an unbalanced force will accelerate an object - changing its speed , its direction , or both its speed and direction .
H1:Please use only words in your input . I am still a young tutor and I do not yet understand mathematical characters , such as +,-,*,/ or = .
A1:if the forces acting upon an object are balanced , then the acceleration of that object will be 0. Objects at equilibrium ( the condition in which all forces balance ) will not accelerate . According to Newton , an object will only accelerate if there is a net or unbalanced force acting upon it . The presence of an unbalanced force will accelerate an object - changing its speed , its direction , or both its speed and direction .

A5:Newton 's second law

A4:Force is equal to the mass times the acceleraiton

A3:The rocket is causing the meteor to accelerate giving it a non-zero net force . According to Newton 's second law of motion , the net force equals mass times acceleration

A2:The acceleration is equal to the force divided by the mass
H1:Yes . We already assessed that : Newton 's second law says that NET FORCE equals MASS times ACCELERATION. A1:constant

INSTANCE: 2121
PROBLEM:A rocket pushes a meteor with constant force . Assume that the meteor is initially at rest and is far enough away from the sun and the planets to neglect gravity . How will the meteor move ?

A2:The meteor will move in the direction of the applied force , in this case being the rocket .
H1:Can you articulate Newton 's second law ?
A1:The acceleration of a body is parallel and directly proportional to the net force acting on the body , is in the direction of the net force , and is inversely proportional to the mass of the body .
Q:Given the non-zero net force acting on the meteor , what does Newton 's second law say about  <np id = "2121_1" min="acceleration"> the acceleration of the meteor </np> ?
A:<p id = "2121_2" refid = "2121_1">It</p> is equal to the net force divided by the mass of the meteor .

INSTANCE: 1733
PROBLEM:To rescue a child who has fallen down a well , rescue workers fasten him to a rope , the other end of which is then reeled in by a machine . H1:Please begin by briefly answering the above question . After briefly answering the above question , please go on to explain your answer in as much detail as you can .
A1:the tension is greater
Q:Remember that tension and downward force of gravity are both vectors . In order for two vectors to be equal , the magnitude and the direction have to be the same . In this case , the tension is upward and gravity is downward . The MAGNITUDES of these vectors can be equal , but the vectors cannot be equal . What does Newton 's first law say about an object 's motion and net force ?
A:nder these conditions <p id = "1733_1" refid = "0">we</p> must realize that a group of forces on an object adds up so that all the forces appear to the object as one force . This one force that is the <np id = "1733_2" min="sum"> sum of all the forces </np> is called the net force . The word net in this context means total . <p id = "1733_3" refid = "1733_2">It</p> is this net force that may change the velocity of the object . Let <p id = "1733_4" refid = "0">us</p> look at some examples .

INSTANCE: 3303
PROBLEM:An airplane is flying on a windy day . The thrust from the plane 's engines is balanced by air resistance such that the plane has a constant component of velocity toward due south . Also , a crosswind pushes the plane with a constant velocity toward due west .

A4:The decomposition principle says that the analyses of forces and motion along two perpendicular directions , such as horizontal and vertical , are independent . That is , Newton 's laws of motion can be applied in each direction without affecting the analysis on the other perpendicular direction .

A1:line .

INSTANCE: 1263
PROBLEM:A mover pushes a desk with constant velocity v0 across a carpeted floor . Suddenly , the mover stops pushing . What can you say about the motion of the desk after the mover stops pushing ? Explain why .
H1:Please begin by briefly answering the above question . After briefly answering the above question , please go on to explain your answer in as much detail as you can .
A1:The desk 's velocity will decrease until it reaches zero because after the force ceases to be applied , the net force will be the force of friction , which acts on the desk in the opposite direction that the force was applied . Newton 's Second Law of Motion states that the object will accelerate in the direction of the net force , therefore the desk 's velocity will decrease .
Q:Which Newton 's law could be useful for solving this problem and why ?
A:<np id = "1263_1" min="Law"> Newton 's Second Law of Motion </np> is useful because <p id = "1263_2" refid = "1263_1">it</p> states that an object will accelerate in the direction of the net force . After the mover stops applying a force , there is a net force opposing motion .
-------------------

H4:Remember that tension and downward force of gravity are both vectors . In order for two vectors to be equal , the magnitude and the direction have to be the same . A4:the two vectors are unbalanced forces with the tension being greater and having an opposite direction of the boy 's weight
