INSTANCE: 3528
PROBLEM:Tim is practicing his air hockey skills by taking shots at an unguarded goal . He hits a frictionless puck so it moves very fast directly towards the goal . His little brother Sam , standing on the side of the table , quickly nudges the puck as it passes the center of the table . The nudge is perpendicular to the original path of the puck .
H6:With this kind of nudge , could the puck 's new path ever be perpendicular to its original path ?
A6:No the puck 's new path could never be perpendicular to its original path
H5:What principle can be applied when analyzing motion in perpendicular directions such as horizontal and vertical directions ?
A5:The decomposition principle and Newton 's First Law
H4:How does the decomposition principle apply to this situation ?
A4:Since the puck 's new path is both horizontal and vertical , then the velocity vector of the path can be broken up as such
H3:In order for the puck 's new path to be completely perpendicular to its original path toward the goal , the puck 's component of velocity in the direction of the goal would have to change to zero . Newton 's laws tells us that a component of net force in the opposite direction from the goal would be necessary to reduce the puck 's component of velocity in the direction of the goal . Since we assume the ice to be frictionless and ignore air resistance , and since Sam 's nudge is perpendicular to the puck 's original path , there are no forces that could change the puck 's component of velocity in the direction of the goal . How does the decomposition principle apply to this situation ?
A3:The decomposition principle allows one to break the vertical and horizontal velocities of the puck into separate parts
H2:Let me try again . We will first analyze the puck 's motion in the direction of the goal , and then __ _ _ _ analyze the puck 's motion in the perpendicular direction . Then , we will __ _ _ _ the information about the puck 's motions in the direction of the goal and in the perpendicular direction to determine the puck 's path .
A2:A
H1:Can you articulate the definition or principle that is most relevant to this problem ?
A1:Newton 's First Law states that an object moving at constant velocity will not accelerate or change direction unless acted upon by an unbalanced force
Q:How does Newton 's first law apply to the puck 's motion in the direction of the goal ?
A:Newton 's First Law applies to <np id = "3528_1" min="puck">the puck</np>'s motion  in the direction of the goal since the puck changed <p id = "3528_2" refid = "3528_1">it</p> 's direction because <p id = "3528_3" refid = "3528_1">it</p> was impacted by the unbalanced force of Sam 's nudging the puck

INSTANCE: 3105
PROBLEM:Two sisters are on a ledge over a deep swimming pool . Sue , the younger and smaller sister , takes a running start and goes straight off the ledge . Paulette , the older and larger sister , simply steps off the ledge at the same moment that Sue leaves the ledge .
H10:Which sister will hit the water first ?
A10:both at the same time due to freefall and gravity
H9:Which principle applies to this situation and why ?
A9:freefall , vectors , gravity because these componets affect the direction and constant speed of certain objects
H8:Let me try again . Which principle helps with solving problems by thinking of motion in two perpendicular directions ?
A8:decomposition method
H7:Good job ! Why is the decomposition principle relevant here ?
A7:it helps us understand the speed and direction of the two girls are equal
H6:The decomposition principle applies to this situation as one of the sisters , Sue , moves both __ _ _ _ _ _ and __ _ _ _ _ _ _ .
A6:horizontally and vertically
H5:How can the decomposition principle be applied to this situation ?
A5:It shows the time and speed both sue and paulette have
H4:Let me try again . Can you think of two perpendicular directions that can be used to solve this problem ?
A4:horizontal and vertical
H3:Perfect ! How can the motion along the horizontal and vertical directions be treated ?
A3:as movement along a coordinate
H2:The __ _ _ _ _ _ and __ _ _ _ _ _ components of motion can be treated __ _ _ _ _ _ according to the decomposition principle .
A2:horizontal and vertical , equally
H1:Can you state a relevant definition or principle ?
A1:that horizontal and vertical movements are treated seperatley , decomposition method
Q:Yes . We already assessed that : The horizontal and vertical components of the motion can be treated separately , according to the decomposition principle . What can you say about <np id = "3105_1" min="objects"> objects near earth </np> upon which the only force acting is the force of gravity exerted by the earth ?
A:<p id = "3105_2" refid = "3105_1">they </p> are at a free fall and in constant motion
-------------------

PROBLEM:A mover pushes a desk with constant velocity v0 across a carpeted floor . Suddenly , the mover stops pushing . What can you say about the motion of the desk after the mover stops pushing ? Explain why .

A6:The desk will stop moving

A5:2nd
H4:Which other Newton 's law could help solve this problem and why ?
A4:2nd
H3:Let me try again . Newton 's __ _ _ _ _ law can help solve this problem as the __ _ _ _ _ _ _ force on the desk becomes non-zero when the mover stops pushing .
A3:3rd
H2:Why the net force acting on the desk is not zero after the mover stops pushing ?
A2:because there is no longer a force
H1:Let me try again . The net force on the desk is non-zero after the mover stops pushing because the only force acting on the desk horizontally is __ _ _ __ .
A1:gravity
Q:What can you say about <np id = "1195_1" min="acceleration">the acceleration of the desk </np> after the mover stops pushing ?
A:<p id = "1195_2" refid = "1195_1">it</p> will decrease

A3:objects at rest stay at rest objects on motion stay in motion and are constant

A2:they are constant

A1:0

A:<p id = "701_2" refid = "701_1">it</p> is moving at a constant speed

INSTANCE: 3251
PROBLEM:Two friends are standing over a bridge over a creek . Each friend has a stone . Sarah throws her stone straight out from the bridge so that its initial velocity is horizontal . At the same time that Sarah 's stone leaves her hand , Billy drops his stone so that it falls straight down .
H7:Which stone will hit the water first ? Please begin by briefly answering the above question . After briefly answering the above question , please go on to explain your answer in as much detail as you can .
A7:they will hit at the same time
H6:What principle can be applied when analyzing motion in perpendicular directions such as horizontal and vertical directions ?
A6:decomposition
H5:How does the decomposition principle apply to this situation ?
A5:the directions are independent of each other
H4:Let me try again . Which direction of motion is relevant to the focus of this problem ?
A4:vertical
H3:Can you state a relevant definition or principle ?
A3:forces in two perpendicular directions can be done independently
H2:Let me try again . What can you say about objects near earth upon which the only force acting is the force of gravity exerted by the earth ?
A2:they fall at the same rate
H1:When only gravity is acting on an object it is said to be in __ _ __ . All objects near the surface of the earth freefall with the same __ _ _ _ downward acceleration regardless of mass ( neglecting the affects of air resistance ) .
A1:freefall velocity
Q:How does the concept of freefall apply in this situation ?
A:only gravity is acting on  <np id = "3251_1" min="stones">the two stones </np> so <p id = "3251_2" refid = "3251_1">they </p> fall at the same rate

INSTANCE: 3075
PROBLEM:Two sisters are on a ledge over a deep swimming pool . Sue , the younger and smaller sister , takes a running start and goes straight off the ledge . Paulette , the older and larger sister , simply steps off the ledge at the same moment that Sue leaves the ledge .
H5:Which sister will hit the water first ?
A5:Paulette because she has a greater mass .
H4:Interestingly , mass does not matter in this problem . Which principle helps with solving problems by thinking of motion in two perpendicular directions ?
A4:momentum

A3:Because the two sisters are jumping in the water at different angles .

A2:forwards , down

A1:Because Sue moves horizontally and vertically

A4:meters per second per second

A3:change of velocity divided by the change of time

A2:They are the same
H1:Perhaps . What is the velocity of each ball at its highest point ?
A1:Zero

A:<p id = "1025_2" refid = "1025_1">They </p> are equal

INSTANCE: 417
PROBLEM:A piano is hanging from a rope near the top floor of a building . The rope suddenly breaks and the piano starts falling . What can you say about the speed of the piano , which initially was at rest before the rope broke ? Assume no other forces are acting on the piano while in free fall .
H5:Please begin by briefly answering the above question . After briefly answering the above question , please go on to explain your answer in as much detail as you can .
A5:The speed of the piano is increasing as the object falls further and the piano accelerates more due to gravity
H4:Which of Newton 's laws can be applied to the falling piano ?
A4:Newton 's Second Law can be applied to the falling piano
H3:Good job ! Why is Newton 's second relevant to the falling piano ?
A3:Since the forces acting on the piano are unbalanced , then one can use Newton 's Second Law to determine the acceleration of the object
H2:Newton 's second law applies because the piano is acted upon with a non-zero __ _ _ _ _ force . The net force is the same as the force of gravity in this case as no other forces act on the piano while on freefall .
A2:downward
H1:Can you articulate Newton 's second law ?
A1:If the net force acting on an object is unbalanced , then that object will accelerate
Q:Let me try again . What does Newton 's second law say about net force , mass , and acceleration ?
A:Newton 's Second Law states that , if an <np id = "417_1" min="object"> object </np> with constant mass , has an unbalanced net force exerted upon <p id = "417_2" refid = "417_1">it</p> , then <p id = "417_2" refid = "417_1">it</p> will accelerate

A5:gravity

A4:Newton 's 3rd Law

A3:Newton 's 1st law
H2:Why is Newton 's second relevant to the falling piano ?
A2:the accleration increases due to gravity and the piano 's mass
H1:Let 's come back to the question before and look for a more precise answer .
A1:The net force equals the mass times the acceleration . They are always in the same direction
Q:Let 's come back to the question before and look for a more precise answer .
A:The speed will be constant if a zero net force acted on the piano .  <np id = "565_1" min="paino">The paino </np> is however in freefall . Gravity then acts upon <p id = "565_2" refid = "565_1">it</p> . Gravity equals the net force

be traveling in ?
A:<p id = "3293_2" refid = "3293_1">It</p> will move on a curved path , in a southwesterly direction .

INSTANCE: 1718
PROBLEM:To rescue a child who has fallen down a well , rescue workers fasten him to a rope , the other end of which is then reeled in by a machine . The rope pulls the child straight upward at steady speed . How does the amount of tension in the rope compare to the downward force of gravity acting on the child ?
H10:Please begin by briefly answering the above question . After briefly answering the above question , please go on to explain your answer in as much detail as you can .
A10:The tension is greater than the oposing force of gravity .
H9:Remember than according to Newton ?s 2nd Law , an imbalance of forces ( or a non-zero net force ) causes an object to accelerate . While its true that in order for the child to start moving , there needs to be an imbalance of forces , in this case we are asking about a moment when the child is already moving and is moving at a constant velocity . What does Newton 's first law say about an object 's motion and net force ?
A9:it will stay at a constant velocity and in a straight line
H8:Newton 's first law says that if an object moves with a constant velocity or is at rest , the net force on the object is __ _ __ .
A8:at rest
H7:What can you say about the net force on the kid ?
A7:it is greater than gravity
H6:Let me try again . What does Newton 's first law tell you about the net force on an object , in this case the kid , when the object moves with constant velocity ?
A6:he will remain in motion in aa straight line and constant velocity unless acted upon by an unbalanced force .
H5:Which forces balance out in this case ?
A5:gravity and normal force
H4:Since the child is being raised straight upward at a constant speed , the __ _ _ _ _ force on the child is __ _ _ _ _ _ and all the forces __ _ _ __ .
A4:net , greater , opposing it
H3:What can you say about the amounts of the tension in the rope pulling the child and the force of gravity pulling the child downwards ?
A3:they are equal
H2:Possibly . What did we find about the net force on the kid based on Newton 's first principle ?
A2:the netforcee is zero
H1:What are the forces acting on the child and which combine in a net forces of zero ?
A1:gravity , tension
Q:Right ! So , how what can you say about  <np id = "1718_1" min="amounts"> the amounts of the tension in the rope and gravity on the child </np> ?
A:<p id = "1718_2" refid = "1718_1">they </p> are equal to zero net force
-------------------
INSTANCE: 1618
PROBLEM:Two hockey players pass a puck between them on an ice rink . Assume that the ice is very smooth so that there is no friction .
H8:What forces are acting on the puck while the puck is moving on the ice between the two players ? Describe the motion of the puck . Please begin by briefly answering the above question . After briefly answering the above question , please go on to explain your answer in as much detail as you can .
A8:the downward force of gravity and normal force
H7:What can you say about net horizontal force on the puck while moving on ice between players ?
A7:it is equal and opposite to the force originally applied by the hockey player 's push
H6:The hockey stick/player can only exert a force on the puck while the puck is in contact with the stick . When the puck is moving between the two players , it is not touching the hockey sticks , so the force from the sticks is not acting on the puck during that time . What can you say about net horizontal force on the puck while moving on ice between players ?
A6:there is none
H5:Let me try again . While the puck is between the players , are there any forces acting on the puck in the horizontal direction ?
A5:no
H4:Given all we learned so far , which of Newton 's laws can be applied to describe the motion of the puck while moving between players ?
A4:3rd law
H3:Let me try again . Which of Newton 's laws describes the motion of objects on which a zero net force is being applied ?
A3:1st law
H2:Can you articulate Newton 's first law ?
A2:an object in motion tends to stay in motion and an object at rest stays at rest unless acted on by an unbalanced force
H1:What can you say about the trajectory and speed of the puck ?
A1:it is constant in one direction
Q:Let me try again . What can you say about the trajectory of the puck given that the net force on  <np id = "1618_1" min="puck">the puck </np> is zero ?
A:<p id = "1618_2" refid = "1618_1">it</p> is constand and traveling in only one direction

INSTANCE: 1522
PROBLEM:Two hockey players pass a puck between them on an ice rink . Assume that the ice is very smooth so that there is no friction .
H10:What forces are acting on the puck while the puck is moving on the ice between the two players ? Describe the motion of the puck . Please begin by briefly answering the above question . After briefly answering the above question , please go on to explain your answer in as much detail as you can .
A10:gravity , normal force , and the force of the hockey sticks acting in the opposite direction of the hockey puck
H9:What can you say about net horizontal force on the puck while moving on ice between players ?
A9:it is equal to the force that the hockey sticks act upon it
H8:The hockey stick/player can only exert a force on the puck while the puck is in contact with the stick . When the puck is moving between the two players , it is not touching the hockey sticks , so the force from the sticks is not acting on the puck during that time . What can you say about net horizontal force on the puck while moving on ice between players ?
A8:it is slowly decreasing
H7:I 'm not sure I understand your input . How about we focus more on our task ?
A7:the net horizontal force on the puck while moving on ice between players is constant
H6:What can you say about net horizontal force on the puck while moving on ice between players ?
A6:it is constant
H5:Let me try again . While the puck is between the players , are there any forces acting on the puck in the horizontal direction ?
A5:there are no forces acting on the puck in the horizontal direction between players
H4:Given all we learned so far , which of Newton 's laws can be applied to describe the motion of the puck while moving between players ?
A4:Newton 's Third Law
H3:Let me try again . Which of Newton 's laws describes the motion of objects on which a zero net force is being applied ?
A3:Newton 's First Law
H2:What can you say about the trajectory and speed of the puck ?
A2:the speed of the puck is constant and the trajectory is equal to that of the force that initial acted upon it
H1:This analysis would be true if we were including the period of time when the puck is touching the hockey stick . The hockey stick would exert a force on the puck causing it to accelerate . For this problem , however , restrict your analysis to only the part of the motion where the puck is between the two players ( not touching them ) . What can you say about the trajectory and speed of the puck ?
A1:the speed is constant and the trajectory is horizontal
Q:Let me try again . What can you say about  <np id = "1522_1" min="trajectory">the trajectory of the puck </np> given that the net force on the puck is zero ?
A:<p id = "1522_2" refid = "1522_1">it</p> is in a straight line

INSTANCE: 1262
PROBLEM:A mover pushes a desk with constant velocity v0 across a carpeted floor . Suddenly , the mover stops pushing . What can you say about the motion of the desk after the mover stops pushing ? Explain why .
Q:Please begin by briefly answering the above question . After briefly answering the above question , please go on to explain your answer in as much detail as you can .
A:<np id = "1262_1" min="velocity">The desk 's velocity </np> will decrease until <p id = "1262_2" refid = "1262_1">it</p> reaches zero because after the force ceases to be applied , the net force will be the force of friction , which acts on the desk in the opposite direction that the force was applied . Newton 's Second Law of Motion states that the object will accelerate in the direction of the net force , therefore the desk 's velocity will decrease .
-------------------
